Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the blood supply of dura matter is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The meningeal branches of the ICA supply dura mater in the anterior and middle cranial fossa, but not in the posterior cranial fossa. Thus, option A is incorrect.

questions.text: At what level does the adult spinal cord terminate in adults?
questions.solution:
The adult spinal cord ends at the level of the middle third of the body of the first lumbar vertebra.

Children- The spinal cord ends at the level of L3.

Filum terminate - Tip of coccyx 

Dural sheath, Subdural space, Subarachnoid space - S2



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 852

questions.text: The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The thyrocervical trunk is a broad, short artery that originates from the front of the first portion of the subclavian artery next to the medial border of scalenus anterior and quickly splits into the inferior thyroid, suprascapular and superficial cervical arteries.

The inferior thyroid artery supplies the lower pole of thyroid gland along with parathyroid gland.

Superior Thyroid artery arises from External carotid artery.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 590

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not felt by the trigeminal nerve's spinal nucleus?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Rather, it is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve present in midbrain.

Spinal nucleus is continuous superiorly with the main sensory nucleus in the pons and extends inferiorly through the whole length of medulla oblongata° and into the upper part of the spinal cord as far as the second cervical segment.

Sensations of pain, temperature touch and pressure from the skin of face and mucous membranes travel along axons whose cell bodies are situated in semilunar or trigeminal sensory ganglion.

 

Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 3437

questions.text: What do Purkinje fibres transfer information to?
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are among the biggest neurons located in the CNS, exhibiting very extensive dendritic structures that branch throughout the molecular layer. The axons of these neurons are the only output from the cerebellar cortex, which projects to the nuclei of the deep cerebellum, specifically the dentate nucleus and form inhibitory synapses with neurons present in the vestibular nuclei.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 469,470

choices.text: Release of catecholamines is not affected by nerve supply to adrenals
Preganglionic fibres from lower thoracic and lumbar vertebra come via sympathetic chain to supply adrenals
Adrenal cortex doesn't have nerve supply as it has endocrine functions

questions.text: What is accurate about the adrenal gland's nerve supply?
questions.solution:
The adrenal glands hold mostly preganglionic sympathetic nerve impulses that start in the lower thoracic segments of the spine, with branches from the coeliac system and plexus, as well as through the greater splanchnic nerve.

The suprarenal gland, relative to its size, has a larger autonomic supply than any other organ. On each side, the suprarenal plexus lies between the medial aspect of the gland and the celiac and aorticorenal ganglia. It contains mostly preganglionic sympathetic fires, which originate in the lower thoracic spinal segments and which reach the plexus via branches from the coeliac ganglion and plexus, and via the greater splanchnic nerve.

Other options:- 

  • Release of catecholamines is affected by the sympathetic nervous system 
  • Adrenal cortex and medulla both have nerve supply




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1239-1242

questions.text: Among the following, which one projects efferent fibres into the designated structure?
questions.solution:
The fornix is the marked structure found in the roof of the third ventricle, beneath the corpus callosum. It is a primary route for output from the hippocampus and an integral part of the limbic system. It terminates in the mammillary body of hippocampus.

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 389

questions.text: Select the option that is incorrectly marked.
questions.solution:
The marked structure B is the pituitary gland, and not the hypothalamus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 389

questions.text: Which of the following structures is indicated in the image below?
questions.solution:
An ultramicroscopic image of a synapse from a brain sample demonstrates presynaptic vesicles.

They are synthesized in the cell body of the pre synaptic neuron and are involved in electrochemical signaling in brain and neuromuscular junction.
The vesicles with neurotransmitters are transferred to the axon terminal with the help of proteins like kinesin and the empty vesicles are transported back to the cell body with the help of proteins like dyenin , It is with the help of this proteins, viruses like rabies virus travels to the CNS. 

Note- The presynaptic secretory vesicles contain neurotransmitters, but neurotransmitter can't be visualized in electron microscopy only the vesicles can be visualized.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 44

questions.text: In which of the following compartments of the leg is there a neurovascular bundle missing?
questions.solution:
The deep posterior compartment is home to the posterior tibial vessels, a branch of the posterior tibial artery and the fibular artery, whilst the anterior compartment is home to the anterior tibial vessels. Furthermore, the superficial posterior compartment has no blood vessels or motor nerves and the artery of the lateral compartment actually lies within the deep posterior compartment.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42 nd Edition Page no 1419-1421

questions.text: All of the aforementioned factors increase GFR, except which one:
questions.solution:
In some disorders related to a blockage of the urinary tract, Bowman's capsule pressure may have an extremely increased level, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This may be caused by the collection of substances like calcium oxide or uric acid, which form stones that block the flow of urine in the ureter, elevating the pressure inside Bowman's capsule, thereby reducing GFR and could eventually create hydronephrosis (swelling and enlargement of the kidney's pelvis and calyces). Unless the obstruction is freed, this could result in damage to, or even destruction of, the kidney.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: Which type of feedback is Baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
The baroreceptor reflex is a rapid negative feedback system which results in the heart rate falling and blood pressure decreasing after an increase in such is detected. If a decrease in blood pressure is detected, the baroreflex is deactivated, which leads to an increase in heart rate and returns the blood pressure back to its typical levels.

 

Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page nos: 8-10

questions.text:
Based on the conductance graph of a neuron presented below, name the ions:


1. Na+ , K+ 
2. K+, Na+ 
3. Na+ , Ca2+ 
4. Ca2+ , Na+
questions.solution:
Na + channels have the ability to open and close rapidly, which facilitates the depolarization phase of action potentials.

On the other hand, K+ channels are responsible for initiating the repolarization phase during action potentials.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 88

questions.text: Three ions—X, Y, and Z—are freely permeable through a cell's cellular membranes. The equilibrium potentials of X and Y are, respectively, -30 mV and -40 mV at resting membrane potential. If a medication that can block Z's permeability is infused, what will happen to the membrane potential?
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) is determined by ionic gradients and permeability of the membrane to ions of different valence. RMP is closest to the equilibrium potential of the ion with maximum permeability, calculated as the sum of the individual permeabilities and reversal potentials of each ion - X, Y, Z - divided by the sum of the individual permeabilities. Blocking ion channels of Z will shift the RMP closer to the reversal potentials of X or Y based on the relative permeability between them. If Z has a reversal potential or original RMP is more negative, closure of its channels will shift the RMP closer to the reversal potentials of X or Y, thus depolarizing the cell.

 

Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 58

choices.text: B has done more work than A
B has both preload and after load added to it
The maximum tension generated will be in A

questions.text:
Select the accurate statement regarding the image given below:


A: Preload                                            B:Afterload
questions.solution:
A - Preload B - Afterload. Preload and afterload are two conditions that affect the force production and work done by a muscle. Preload occurs when the muscle is passively stretched by the load in its relaxed state, leading to an increased overlap of thin and thick filaments in the sarcomere and increased active tension. Afterload occurs when the load acts only on the muscle while it is in active contraction and is supported during relaxed state. Work done is higher during afterload, as displacement is higher and the load is acting on the muscle more forcefully.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 535

questions.text: What is the effect on end systolic volume (ESV) during exercise in physiological limits?
questions.solution:
Exercising leads to an increase in venous return to the heart, resulting in higher end-diastolic volume, but the greater contractility of the heart and elevated stroke volume offset this increase and cause the end-systolic volume to decrease.

 

Reference-: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page 308-309

questions.text: Select the correct diluting segment of kidney.
questions.solution:
The Loop of Henle allows for water to be removed from the filtrate in the nephron by passing it through a hypertonic interstitium. The descending limb is permeable to water through aquaporin-I, while Na, K and Cl are cotransported out in the thick segment of the ascending limb, thus leading to fluid in the descending limb becoming hypertonic and ascending limb hypotonic. This results in approximately 20% of filtered water entering the distal tubule, with a TF/P of inulin of 5. The ascending limb vidly reabsorbs most of the ions, including sodium, potassium, and chloride, but is virtually impermeable to water and urea. For this reason, it is referred to as the diluting segment because it also dilutes the tubular fluid.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 674

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How an electrical synapse is different from a chemical synapse?
questions.solution:
Connexons, comprise clusters of ion channels that directly connect the cytoplasms of two adjacent cells and allow ions to be moved freely between the two interiors. These connexons line up in the membranes of both cells to form a dodecameric gap junction that is up to 4nm across. Electrical synapse impulse is bidirectional, it's also faster and has less latent time. 


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 43

questions.text: What enzyme deficiency obstructs the production of vitamin C in humans?
Which of these is absent from the Klenow fragment's activity?
questions.solution:
The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase is used for random primer labelling because it lacks a 5'-> 3' exonuclease activity. This is prepared by cleavage of DNA polymerase with subtilisin, giving a large enzyme fragment which has no 5' - 3' exonuclease activity, but still acts as 5'- 3 'polymerase.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 402.

questions.text: Which of the following methods has RNA as its foundation?
questions.solution:
PCR facilitates the expansion and study of DNA extracted from single cells, hair follicles, or spermatozoa and thus has plenty of utilization in forensic medicine. Apart from that, it is also used to detect hidden viruses, diagnose fetal genetic issues, identify gene polymorphisms, confirm tissue types of transplants and analyze the evolution via retroviral reverse transcriptase-derived c DNA copies of mRNA (RT-PCR method).

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: What one of the following is not required to have a 5' capping?
questions.solution:
Capping is a process which protects 5' end of mRNA and polyadenylation protects 3' end against the action of exonucleases. 

mRNA, snRNA and siRNA undergo this process but tRNA and rRNA are relatively stable. Hence, they do not undergo capping at the 5' end. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: What alteration of the cytosine residues at CpG islands in DNA does not favour permissive euchromatin?
questions.solution:
Methylation causes inactivation of DNA and inhibits the formation of transcriptionally active euchromatin. 

It is an example of epigenetic modification. Examples include

1. Methylation of cytosine residues in CpG islands
2. Modification of histones by acetylation or methylation
3. Changes in high order chromatin structure. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: Substrate is present in a process at a concentration 1000 times higher than the enzyme's Km value. 1% of the substrate is converted to product (12 micrograms/ml) after 9 minutes of reaction. if the substrate concentration is doubled and the enzyme concentration is changed to 1/3. How long does it take to transform a substrate into a product with a 12 microgram/ml yield?
questions.solution:
The given reaction is an example of zero order kinetics since the substrate concentration is much higher than Km value. 
 

Vo = Vmax [ S ] / Km + [S]

So, Vmax = K2[Et]

If total enzyme concentration is reduced by 1/3 and [S] is very high then V also becomes 1/3.

 So in this question the same amount of product will be formed in 27 minutes (3 × 9 min).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: A woman complained of being worn out and having tingling in her hands and legs. She exhibits  a fissured red tongue, lesions at the angle of the mouth, and decreased RBC glutathione reductase activity upon testing. What vitamin is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
Symptoms such as cheilosis, glossitis and angular stomatitis may be observed along with a decreased activity of glutathione reductase in red blood cells, which is typically associated with a riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin deficiency: Activity of glutathione reductase in erythrocytes gives a functional index of flavin coenzyme activity. Cofactor-induced increase of 20% above the basal level indicates deficiency.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 154.

questions.text: Which of the following improves iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Inorganic iron is only absorbed in its reduced state, so the presence of reducing agents such as vitamin C, ethanol, fructose and heme iron from meat can enhance its absorption.

A daily intake of 40-60 mg of vitamin C and 25-50 mg per meal will be beneficial, however, calcium can reduce absorption of both inorganic and heme iron, so should be avoided with meals.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 539.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has decreased activity when you're fasting?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is: 3. Acetyl Co-A carboxylase.
  • The enzyme that has decreased activity when fasting is acetyl Co-A carboxylase.
  • Acetyl Co-A carboxylase is a key enzyme in fatty acid synthesis and is inhibited by glucagon during fasting to prevent energy storage.
Other options
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase has increased activity as it is activated by glucagon and epinephrine, leading to triglyceride breakdown.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase also has increased activity as it promotes glycogen breakdown to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase has increased activity as it helps in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, releasing glucose into the bloodstream.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no166.

questions.text: A male adolescent patient complained of calf soreness during activity. A biopsy revealed that the muscle had an abnormal amount of glycogen. What type of enzyme deficit is most likely?
questions.solution:
Type V Glycogen Storage Disease (Muscle Phosphorylase Deficiency, McArdle Disease): GSD V is caused by the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase activity. Lack of this enzyme limits muscle ATP generation by glycogenolysis, resulting in muscle glycogen accumulation, and is the prototype of muscle energy disorders. Deficiency of myophosphorylase impairs the cleavage of glucosyl molecules from the straight chain of glycogen.

Symptoms are generally characterized by exercise intolerance with muscle cramps and pain. Two types of activity tend to cause symptoms: brief exercise of great intensity, such as sprinting or carrying heavy loads; and less intense but sustained activity, such as climbing stairs or walking uphill.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: Which metabolic process is inhibited by fluoride produced from fluoroacetate?
Which enzyme is responsible for regenerating vitamin K in its coenzyme form?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 4. Epoxide reductase.
Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that is essential for blood clotting and bone health. Vitamin K is converted to its active form, vitamin K hydroquinone, during the carboxylation of certain proteins involved in blood clotting. During this process, vitamin K hydroquinone is oxidized to vitamin K epoxide. In order to be reused, vitamin K epoxide must be reduced back to vitamin K hydroquinone. This reduction reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme epoxide reductase.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 533.

questions.text: What is the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
Complementation is a process in genetics where two strains of an organism with different homozygous recessive mutations that produce the same mutant phenotype, such as a change in wing structure in flies, are mated or crossed and the offspring has a wild-type phenotype. The blue-white assay is a technique used to screen for and detect gene uptake during genetic engineering based on the principle of alpha-complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene. A defective galactosidase gene product activity is complemented by a similarly defective gene product from a plasmid, which together become active. This can be used to determine a successful gene uptake as it disrupts the plasmid gene product and complementation cannot occur, resulting in white colonies and an unsuccessful gene insertion will result in blue colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 445.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for the presence and concentrations of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites.

Abnormalities in metabolite levels can serve as diagnostic indicators for a variety of genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 270.

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.text: An infant who had experienced vomiting and malnutrition arrived to the OPD. The Guthrie test was discovered to be positive after an investigation. Regarding this illness, all of the following are accurate, excluding:
questions.solution: Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: Which is the best method to measure HbA1c?
questions.solution:
The four most commonly used methods for determining HbAlc levels are immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays. Immunoassays typically measure HbAlc specifically, as antibodies detect the structure of the N-terminal glycated amino acids (which typically consist of the first 4-10 amino acids) of the Hb B chain. On the other hand, ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on the contrast in charge between HbA1c and the other hemoglobins. Thus, Best method is ion exchange chromatography.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: All of the following can result from abnormal elastin protein, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Abnormalities in elastin can lead to a number of conditions, including aortic aneurysms, joint laxity and subluxation of the lens. These conditions are not linked to fractures. Abnormality in elastin occurs in Marfan's syndrome. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 597.

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised man arrived with a fever and shortness of breath. A middle lobe lesion with infiltration was seen on HRCT. The image displays a lung biopsy taken from the lesion. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CMV pneumonia 
 
  • This diagnosis was suggested due to a middle-aged immunocompromised male presenting with a history of fever and breathlessness, and HRCT showing a middle lobe lesion with infiltration.
  • Analysis of the lung biopsy image revealed many cells with intranuclear inclusions, suggesting CMV pneumonia as the likely diagnosis.
  • In immunosuppressed individuals, such as transplant recipients and HIV-infected individuals, CMV infection can lead to severe, life-threatening problems, particularly of the lungs and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Pneumonia caused by CMV is characterized by an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis along with enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusions. This can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • The intestinal infection can lead to intestinal necrosis and ulceration which can cause pseudo membranes and debilitating diarrhea.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1139.

choices.text: Rolling → Stable adhesion →Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium
Rolling → Activation of integrins → Stable adhesion → Migration via endothelium
Stable adhesion → Rolling → Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium
Activation of integrins → Migration via endothelium→ Stable adhesion → Rolling

questions.text: Which of the following best describes how cells behave during acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rolling → Activation of integrins → Stable adhesion → Migration via endothelium 

The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines.

* This process can be divided into sequential phases- 

1. In the lumen: margination, rolling, and adhesion to endothelium. Vascular endothelium in its normal state does not bind circulating cells or allow their passage. In inflammation the endothelium is activated and can bind leukocytes as a prelude to their exit from blood vessels.
2. Migration across the endothelium and vessel wall.
3. Migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus.


Fig: The multistep process of leukocyte migration through blood vessels.
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy was diagnosed with proptosis. When the mass was examined under a microscope, a round cell tumour that was immunohistochemically positive for desmin was discovered. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma
 
  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimics skeletal muscle at various stages of embryogenesis and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma.
  • A diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma is usually made by looking at the specimen under the microscope and finding evidence of characteristic rhabdomyoblasts.
  • Immunohistochemical staining for muscle-specific proteins such as myosin, actin, desmin, and myoglobin can be used to confirm the diagnosis.
  • There are three types of rhabdomyosarcoma, of which embryonal is the most common, accounting for over two-thirds of cases. Of the two subtypes of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid and spindle cell, the latter tends to be associated with a more favorable prognosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 995.

questions.text: For acidic mucin, which of the following stains is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Alcin Blue

  • The alcian blue stain has the ability to distinguish between sialomucins, sulfomucins, and proteoglycans which are stained blue.
  • Neutral mucins on the other hand, will demonstrate a deep red/magenta staining with the PAS.
  • On a tissue or cellular level, the reaction of both neutral and acidic mucins will display varying shades of purple since they interact differently with the alcian blue and react with the Schiff reagent.
Other options: -
  • MPO stain is used for detecting Myeloperoxidase
  • Masson's trichrome is used for staining collagen
  • PTAH stain is used to identify contraction band necrosis
Online Reference: Kameyama A, Dong W. Succinylation-Alcian blue staining for mucins. 2021 Oct 1 [Updated 2022 Mar 24]. In: Nishihara S, Angata K, Aoki-Kinoshita KF, et al., editors. Glycoscience Protocols (GlycoPODv2) [Internet]. Saitama (JP): Japan Consortium for Glycobiology and Glycotechnology; 2021-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK593966/

questions.text: Which laboratory test is the best among the following to detect bleeding in disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increased FDPs
 
  • In the case of acute DIC, there is a swift activation of coagulation leading to bleeding, with low platelet count, prolonged PT and APTT, low fibrinogen and elevated FDP and D-dimer levels.
  • On the other hand, in chronic DIC, the activation of coagulation is slow, and although there may be a normal platelet count, usual PT and APTT, elevated FDP and D-dimer levels are still present.
  • Therefore, if the DIC is acute, all options are valid, but if it is chronic, increased FDP would be the correct answer.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 669.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy's biopsy of his swollen leg revealed small, spherical, blue tumour cells compatible with the diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. What test will be most effective for identifying the translocation t(11;22) in this cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) FISH
 
  • FISH is a diagnostic tool to detect chromosomal abnormalities, gene mutations and gene amplification. It can be performed on various samples such as blood, tissue samples and even archived tissue slides.
  • Chromosome painting is an extension of FISH which uses probes to span the entire chromosome. However, the number of chromosomes that can be detected are limited by the availability of fluorescent dyes.
  • Spectral karyotyping (also called multicolor FISH) is a breakthrough technique in which different mixtures of five fluorochromes in specific probes are used to visualize the entire human genome. This technique can truly be called “spectacular karyotyping.”
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: A worker who had spent the previous 20 years working in a manufacturing suddenly had pleural thickening and fibrosis. The graphic below depicts the lesion's histopathology. Most likely medical condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Asbestosis 

The diagnosis of asbestosis is suggested due to the presence of pleural thickening, fibrosis, and asbestos bodies found on the image.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center which are formed when macrophages phagocytize asbestos fibers, and the iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.
  • In addition, other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes which are known as ferruginous bodies. This diagnosis is further supported by the history of working in an asbestos factory for 20 years.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

choices.text: Should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from blood bank
Should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from blood bank
Wait till the patient is stable then transfuse, irrespective of any timing
Should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from blood bank

questions.text: Which of the following statements about packed RBC blood transfusions is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from blood bank 
 
  • RBCs are to be transfused within four hours of issue from the blood bank because of the risk of hemolysis. When RBCs sit at room temperature, the temperature can rise and cause the cells to burst, leading to potentially life-threatening consequences. To prevent this, RBCs should be transfused within four hours.
  • Additionally, red blood cells (RBCs) are fragile cells. When RBCs are transfused, it is important to use a needle that is thin enough to minimize trauma to the cells but still large enough to provide an adequate transfusion rate. A 18-20 G needle is the optimal size for delivering red blood cells. 
  • Opened bags must be used within 6 h. Following transfusion, the transfusion set has to be closed in sterile fashion and retained, together with the empty bag, for 24 h at a temperature of + 1°C to + 10°C.
Online Reference: Müller MM, Geisen C, Zacharowski K, Tonn T, Seifried E. Transfusion of Packed Red Cells: Indications, Triggers and Adverse Events. Dtsch Arztebl Int. 2015 Jul 20;112(29-30):507-17; quiz 518. doi: 10.3238/arztebl.2015.0507. PMID: 26249256; PMCID: PMC4555065.

questions.text: The following are detected using toluidine blue staining:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Mast cell
 
  • Toluidine blue is a stain that can differentiate basophils and mast cells based upon its chemical reaction with acid mucopolysaccharides present in the cell granules.
  • This form of staining, however, may not be effective when the level of acid mucopolysaccharides are low - as seen in malignant mast cells or basophils. To identify this type of cell more definitively, immunohistochemical markers, such as staining for mast cell tryptase, can be used in replacement of toluidine blue staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 206.

questions.text: RBCs, platelets, and fresh frozen plasma (FEP) are stored at the following temperatures:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) RBC 2-6°C, Platelet 20-22°C, FFP-30°C

* Storage temperature of:
  1. RBC 2-6°C,
  2. Platelet 20-22°C,
  3. FFP-30°C.
Blood storage: -
  • PRBC- SAGM- 42 days- 2-6 degree Celsius 
  • Platelet- 5 days- 20-24 degree Celsius (room temperature)
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma- 1 year- -30 degree Celsius 
  • Cryoprecipitate- 2 years- less than -30 degree Celsius 

Under these conditions, there is minimal loss of activity of the labile coagulation factors V and VIII.
One milliliter of FFP contains approximately one unit of coagulation factor activity. After thawing, FFP may be stored in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours before use.

Online Reference: Basu D, Kulkarni R. Overview of blood components and their preparation. Indian J Anaesth. 2014 Sep;58(5):529-37. doi: 10.4103/0019-5049.144647. PMID: 25535413; PMCID: PMC4260297.

questions.text: Which of the following, according to the WHO's 2016 categorization of acute leukemia, is not a temporary entity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) AML with hyper diploidy
 
  • In response to the WHO 2016 classification, AML with hyper ploidy is not a provisional entity because it is simply a subtype of AML, and not a distinct entity in and of itself.
  • Hyper ploidy refers to an increase in the number of chromosomal copies in each cell, which can occur in both myelodysplastic syndromes and certain types of AML.
  • The WHO 2016 classification recognizes the importance of this finding but does not consider it to be a separate entity, since it is not distinct from the underlying disease of AML.
WHO 2022 Classification of AML


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 810.

questions.text: Which of the following designations best describes the microscope's condenser?
questions.solution:
For the given image, structure marked C corresponds to condenser.

   

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 10.

questions.text: A 12-year-old youngster suffered a cut on his forearm four days prior. Due to the creation of granulation tissue, the bleeding has now stopped. A portion of the granulation tissue was also included in the material when conducting a skin biopsy. Below is a diagram illustrating granulation tissue's histology. This granulation tissue contains what kind of collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Type 3
 
  • In the given image, we can see that the granulation tissue is 4 days old, which means that the matrix is still composed of type III collagen, fibrin, plasma fibronectin and other components.
  • This matrix is in the process of being replaced by a matrix predominantly composed of type I collagen. Eventually, this will convert into a pale, avascular scar, containing spindle-shaped fibroblasts, collagen fragments, and other ECM components.
* Timeline Of Wound Healing by Primary Intention:
 
  • Within 24 hours, neutrophils are seen at the incision margin, migrating toward the fibrin clot.
  • Within 24 to 48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges have begun to migrate and proliferate along the dermis yielding a thin but continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound.
  • By day 3, neutrophils have been largely replaced by macrophages, and granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space.
  • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space.
  • During the second week, there is continued collagen accumulation and fibroblast proliferation.
  • By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: All of the following contain type I collagen, with the exception of which:
questions.solution:
Type I collagen is the most predominant type found in the dermis, fasciae, bone, tendon, ligaments, and blood vessels, as well as the sclera of the eyeball; however, type II collagen is the specific type characteristic of cartilage, as well as the vitreous body of the eye.

Trick:-
Cartilage- spell Cart-two-lage- Collagen 2

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 593.

questions.text: What among the following functions via G-protein coupled receptors?
questions.solution:
All the muscarinic receptors which are known are G-protein-linked receptors that interact with different cellular mediators.

1. Nuclear receptors- Sex hormones 
2. Cell membrane receptors- GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase receptors 
  •  Tyrosine Kinase - Remember PIG - Prolactin, Insulin, GH
  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 59

questions.text: An appetite loss and abdominal distention have been present for the last week in a 50-year-old male with fever. Antibiotics and malaria medications are having no effect on it. RK39 dipstick test is positive but Widal test is negative. Which medications are appropriate for the patient mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Liposomal amphotericin B
 
  • The rK39 dipstick test is an immunochromatographic method commonly employed to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of therapy for this condition is liposomal amphotericin B, considered to be first line treatment since resistance to sodium stibogluconate has increased in some regions.
  • Doses of 3-4 mg/kg daily are known to be effective for treating visceral leishmaniasis with L-AMB.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 903.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below ought to only be available with a doctor's prescription?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Schedule H drugs

Under Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945, Schedule H is a class of prescription drugs, which cannot be purchased over the counter without the prescription of a qualified doctor.

* Schedule H drug Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a Registered Medical Practitioner only.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: Which of the following provides a graph showing the rate of medication absorption in plasma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tmax and Cmax 

Tmax - Time to attain the peak plasma concentration
Cmax - Peak plasma concentration These give the rate of drug absorption in plasma concentration graphs.

Bioavailability refers to the rate and extent of absorption of a drug from a dosage form administered by any route, as determined by its concentration-time curve.
  • Rate of drug absorption - Tmax and Cmax.
  • Extent of drug absorption - Area under the curve (AUC).

 Diagram: Formulation B is more slowly absorbed than A, and though ultimately both are absorbed to the same extent (area under the curve same).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following ways is most likely to result in 100% bioavailability of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Intravenous 

* Intravenous drug route:
 
  • Factors limiting absorption i.e., Aqueous solubility, Concentration, Area of absorbing surface and Vascularity of the absorbing surface etc. are circumvented by intravenous injection of drugs in aqueous solution because bioavailability is complete and rapid.
  • Also, drug delivery is controlled and achieved with an accuracy and immediacy not possible by any other procedure.

Bioavailability of drug injected via intravenous route is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because—

(a) the drug may be incompletely absorbed.
(b) the absorbed drug may undergo first pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/liver or be excreted in bile.

* Incomplete bioavailability after subcutaneous or intramuscular injection is less common but may occur due to local binding of the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following medication delivery methods will not circumvent hepatic first-pass metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Oral 
 
  • When drugs are taken orally, they may not be absorbed by the body as much as they should be.
  • This is due to two main factors: the incomplete extent of the drug being absorbed by the gut wall and the liver being able to break down or eliminate the drug before it has a chance to be absorbed.
  • As a result, the bioavailability of the drug is less than 100%.
  • All orally administered drugs are exposed to drug metabolizing enzymes in the intestinal wall and liver (where they first reach through the portal vein).
  • Presystemic metabolism in the gut and liver can be avoided by administering the drug through sublingual, transdermal or parenteral routes.

* Clinical points about drugs with high first pass metabolism:

(a) Oral dose is considerably higher than sublingual or parenteral dose.

(b) There is marked individual variation in the oral dose due to differences in the extent of first pass metabolism.
(c) Oral bioavailability is apparently increased in patients with severe liver disease.
(d) Oral bioavailability of a drug is increased if another drug competing with it in first pass metabolism is given concurrently, e.g. chlorpromazine and propranolol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

choices.text: Azoles (fluconazole, itraconazole, miconazole): Inhibit lanosterol alpha demethylase thereby preventing ergosterol synthesis
Flucytosine: Inhibit microtubules synthesis thus preventing mitosis
Echinocandins (Caspofungin): act by inhibiting beta 1,3 glucan synthesis
Amphotericin B binds with ergosterol resulting in disruption of cell membrane causing micropores and leakage of ions and cell death

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of action of anti-fungal medications is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flucytosine: Inhibit microtubules synthesis thus preventing mitosis 
 
  • The uptake of flucytosine by fungal cells is facilitated by cytosine permease.
  • It is then transformed through various steps into 5-FU, 5-fluorodeoxyuridine monophosphate (FdUMP), and fluorouridine triphosphate (FUTP), which prevent DNA and RNA synthesis respectively.
  • This conversion is not able to happen in human cells, so flucytosine has selective toxicity which does not impede microtubule synthesis.

 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 843.

questions.text: Which antifungal medication, which has not been used for Tinea corporis and Tinea cruris over the past two years, is developing drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Griseofulvin 
 
  • Griseofulvin is an oral medication used for the treatment of tinea infection.
  • Unfortunately, its efficacy has been diminishing in recent years due to an increase in resistant strains, leading to its replacement by more effective antifungal agents, such as terbinafine and itraconazole, as the go-to medication.
  • Topical application is not effective with this drug.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1204.

questions.text: The newest medication for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Edaravone
 
  • The recently sanctioned medicine for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is Edaravone. The US FDA authorized it on the grounds of a six-month test including a specific set of ALS sufferers, which showed a small decline in their disability rate.
  • Edavarone acts as an antioxidant, however the actual mechanism of action is not known.
  • This drug, thought to act as an antioxidant, is administered through a 10-day cycle of daily intravenous infusions, each month. Previously, Riluzole was approved, albeit with a mild survival extension benefit. However, survival was not an inspected factor in the Edaravone trial.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 423.
Online Reference:
Cruz MP. Edaravone (Radicava): A Novel Neuroprotective Agent for the Treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. P T. 2018 Jan;43(1):25-28. PMID: 29290672; PMCID: PMC5737249.

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. There are 10 divisions per millilitre in your 2 ml syringe. 500 mg/5 ml of ceftriaxone are present in the vial. To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone, how many divisions in a 2 ml syringe should you fill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 18

To give the patient 180 mg of ceftriaxone, 1.8 mL of drug solution is required in a 2 mL syringe. This holds 10 divisions per mL, equalling 18 divisions being filled in the syringe.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amikacin 
 
  • Amikacin, a widely used aminoglycoside, does not have Salmonella in its antimicrobial spectrum, but is often employed for treating gentamicin and tobramycin resistant diseases, as well as MDR-TB.
  • It also works efficiently against Pseudomonas, Proteus and Serratia.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 762.

questions.text: It was determined that a patient from the northeastern states had P. falciparum malaria. What medication is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Artemether plus lumefantrine
 
  • The most effective medication for a patient with a Plasmodium falciparum malaria infection is a combination of artemether and lumefantrine.
  • This combination is specifically designed to treat acute, uncomplicated cases of falciparum malaria acquired in areas in which P. falciparum is resistant to chloroquine and antifolate drugs. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 889.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is frequently prescribed to treat cancer-related thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Low molecular weight heparin 
 
  • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is a preferred treatment for cancer-associated thromboembolism.
  • Direct oral anticoagulants are the preferred first-line treatment for venous thromboembolism in non-cancer patients, but LMWH is still preferred for those with active cancer.
  • LMWH is also used for out-of-hospital management of patients with venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism as it does not require laboratory monitoring and reduces healthcare expenditures.
  • Warfarin is less preferred in cancer patients due to nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy, liver involvement, and poor venous access. LMWH is sometimes used as a long-term therapy instead of warfarin.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Doxycycline

Orientia tsutsugamushi is the bacteria that causes scrub typhus, which is transmitted by tiny mites or chiggers.
Doxycycline is the recommended medication to treat scrub typhus.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

choices.text: Increase secretion of both insulin and C-peptide

questions.text: The potassium ionophore valinomycin has the following effects on pancreatic beta cells:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Decrease the secretion of insulin 
 
  • Valinomycin is a natural neutral ionophore account for its lack of a residual charge, allowing it to move potassium ions through membranes as it acts as a potassium-specific transporter.
  • It increases the permeability of potassium ions which results in hyperpolarization of beta cells and inhibiting the release of insulin.
Online Reference:
Huang S, Liu Y, Liu WQ, Neubauer P, Li J. The Nonribosomal Peptide Valinomycin: From Discovery to Bioactivity and Biosynthesis. Microorganisms. 2021 Apr 8;9(4):780. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms9040780. PMID: 33917912; PMCID: PMC8068249.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia
 
  • The use of Beta-2 agonists, such as salbutamol, can cause an increase in plasma glucose as a result of stimulating the processes of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.
  • This usually leads to hyperglycemia, but in large doses it can also lead to metabolic side effects including a rise in fatty acids, insulin, glucose, pyruvate, and lactate.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: Which medication among the following results in flagellate skin pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bleomycin
 
  • Bleomycin can cause a flagellate dermatitis consisting of bands of pruritic erythema on the arms, back, scalp and hands, which can be treated with topical corticosteroids.
  • The most serious adverse reaction to bleomycin is pulmonary toxicity, with signs such as dry cough, fine rales, and diffuse basilar infiltrates on X-ray.
  • This can progress to life-threatening pulmonary fibrosis and radiological changes which may be indistinguishable from interstitial infection or tumor, showing strong PET-positivity and ranging from patchy infiltrates to dense fibrosis, cavitation and pneumothorax, atelectasis, or lobar collapse.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1370.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is frequently prescribed for community-acquired pneumonia in the OPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Azithromycin

Azithromycin, as a 500-mg loading dose, followed by a 250-mg single daily dose for the next 4 days, is commonly used alone or in combination with a beta-lactam antibiotic to treat community-acquired pneumonia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 804.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sialorrhea 
 
  • Escitalopram is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).
  • SSRIs have side effects, including insomnia, increased anxiety, irritability, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, anorgasmia, ejaculatory delay and gastrointestinal effects.
  • Some patients also experience increased anxiety during the initial dosing, and dullness of intellectual ability and concentration with continued treatment.
  • Paroxetine in particular is linked to higher levels of sexual side effects. Sialorrhea is not the side-effect of SSRIs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: The intern administered an antiemetic medicine to a patient who had a history of a few episodes of vomiting. A few hours later, the patient's posture began to change. Which of the following medication administrations is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Metoclopramide
 
  • Metoclopramide has a central anti-dopaminergic (D2) action on the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), which is the primary cause of its antiemetic property.
  • This action of metoclopramide also leads to certain major side effects such as extrapyramidal effects like dystonias, akathisia and parkinsonian features that are observed in individuals who take the drug to control vomiting.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: Which of the following medications' withdrawal can result in anxiety and insomnia leading to discontinuation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Venlafaxine
 
  • Venlafaxine is an SNRI, a type of medication that can cause anxiety, insomnia and other adverse reactions if stopped suddenly.
  • SNRIs have similar side effects to SSRIs, including nausea, constipation, insomnia, headaches, and sexual dysfunction.
  • Higher doses of the immediate release form of venlafaxine can cause high blood pressure, but this is lowered when taken in extended-release form.
  • Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI therefore has withdrawal symptoms.
  • Duloxetine, another SNRI, does not have this same side effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: Which of the following adjuvants does heparin operate through?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Antithrombin III
 
  • Heparin acts through Antithrombin III adjuvant by binding to and activating Antithrombin III (ATIII).
  • ATIII normally circulates in the bloodstream in an inactive form, but when it binds to heparin it becomes activated.
  • The active form of ATIII, in turn, binds to and inactivates a number of key coagulation factors, including thrombin and factor Xa. This prevents thrombosis by inhibiting clot formation.
  • Additionally, heparin may also facilitate the fibrinolysis process by activating plasminogen and allowing it to break down fibrin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 663.

questions.text: What is the therapeutic index a measure of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Safety

The therapeutic index of a drug is a measure of its safety, because it means that a high value creates a wide space between doses that can cause harm.

The median lethal dose (LD50) and median effective dose (ED50) are used to measure the therapeutic index of a drug: the ratio between the dose required to produce a desired effect and the dose necessary to cause the drug's adverse effects.

Therapeutic window is a range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity. In clinical studies, the dose or concentration required to produce toxic effects can be compared to concentrations that produce therapeutic effects to evaluate the clinical therapeutic index.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 65.

questions.text: What does the loading dose of a drug depend upon
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution 

Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
Thus, loading dose is governed only by V and not by CL or t½.

Variables are used to calculate the loading dose:
  • Cp = desired peak concentration of drug,
  • F = bioavailability, 
  • Vss = volume of distribution of drug at steady state,
                                                                                   Loading dose= Cp*Vss/F
    

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

questions.text: 500 mg of paracetamol are listed on the label by the drug's manufacturer. Analysis revealed that it barely contained 200 milligrammes of the substance. What class of drug is it considered to be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Counterfeit drug

Counterfeit medicine is a fake product, which might be contaminated or have the incorrect or absent active ingredients. They may also have the right active ingredient, but not in the amount labelled on the drug company's label. For example, if the label says the product contains 500 mg of paracetamol, but upon analysis only 200 mg is present, then it is a counterfeit drug. It's not adulterant drug because there is no addition of other drug or substance.

* Other options:-

2. Spurious drug- False identity drugs that deceive buyers 
3. Adulterant drug- Is substance mixed with drug which is not a constituent of it to reduce the quality
4. Unethical drug- no such term exist

Online Reference:
Pathak R, Gaur V, Sankrityayan H, Gogtay J. Tackling Counterfeit Drugs: The Challenges and Possibilities. Pharmaceut Med. 2023 Jul;37(4):281-290. doi: 10.1007/s40290-023-00468-w. Epub 2023 May 15. PMID: 37188891; PMCID: PMC10184969.

choices.text: Tenofovir: Inhibits assembly of proviral components into viral proteins
Enfuvirtide: An entry inhibitor, inhibits viral entry by binding to CCR5  receptor
Dolutegravir: Inhibits integration of viral DNA into host

questions.text: Which of the following medications matches its mode of action correctly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dolutegravir: Inhibits integration of viral DNA into host 

Integrase Strand Transfer Inhibitors (INSTIs) are antiviral agents that bind to the integrase enzyme of HIV-1 and HIV-2 and prevent the third and final stage of viral DNA integration into host cell chromosomes.
Dolutegravir is an INSTI that inhibits the integration of viral DNA into the host cell, successfully halting the replication of the virus.

*Trick- Anti HIV drugs ending with suffix -gravir are integrase inhibitors.

* [Extra Edge]: Anti-Retroviral Drug-
 
MECHANISM OF ACTION  EXAMPLE
NRTIs Zidovudine
Emtricitabine
Tenofovir
Lamivudine
NNRTIs Nevirapine
Efavirenz
PIs Ritonavir
Indinavir
Lopinavir
Entry inhibitor Enfuvirtide
CCR-5R inhibitor Maraviroc
INSTIs Raltegravir
Deglutagravir


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 867.

questions.text: The organism that causes ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is usually:
questions.solution:
Acinetobacter baumannii is a common cause of nosocomial pneumonia, especially in people who require extended periods of mechanical ventilation.

Symptoms of hospital-acquired or ventilator-associated pneumonia caused by this bacteria are consistent with other nosocomial pathogens, characterized by fever and increased production of mucus. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: Which of the following is not connected to HHV8
questions.solution:
HHV-8 does not cause T-cell leukemia. It's known to cause 1. Kaposi sarcoma 2. Primary effusion lymphoma 3. Castleman disease HTLV-1 is associated with Adult T-cell Leukemia.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: Choose the creature according to its life cycle:
questions.solution:
The given  life cycle of Influenza A virus. It  is divided into four distinct stages:

1. Attachment: Also known as the adsorption phase, this is the stage in which the influenza virus attaches to a suitable host cell. This is done through the influenza virus surface glycoproteins, haemagglutinin and neuraminidase.

2. Penetration: The virus then penetrates the host cell membrane and begins to uncoat, releasing its genetic material inside the host cell.

3. Replication: The virus then begins to express its enzymes, allowing it to replicate within the host cell and create daughter virus particles.

4. Release: In the final stage, the viral particles will spread and infect new cells, allowing the virus to continue to spread and accelerate infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 503.

questions.text: On the bacitracin sensitivity disc test, identify the organism:
questions.solution:
The results of the bacitracin sensitivity disk test are indicative of Streptococcus pyogenes, which generate large clear zones of B-hemolysis (approx 1 cm in diameter) surrounding colonies larger than 0.5 mm. S. pyogenes is also PYR-positive (hydrolytion of I-pyrrolidonyl-B-naphthylamide) and usually sensitive to bacitracin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 217.

questions.text: A known HIV patient using anti-retroviral medication reported having diarrhoea for six months. Kinyoun stain was positive after stool microscopy revealed 10–30 micrometre cysts. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Cystoisospora (Isospora) belli is the causative agent of malabsorption, fever, and chronic diarrhoea in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) patients. Infections are characterized by sudden fever, abdominal pain, and watery (non-bloody) diarrhoea that lasts for weeks or months in those with severe immunosuppression. Diagnosis is usually made through detection of the large (~25-um) oocysts in stool with Kinyoun stain and modified acid-fast staining.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 96.

questions.text: A child who had been experiencing stomach pain for 10 days visited OPD. The results of stool microscopy are displayed. What medication is recommended for the illness brought on by the specified organism
questions.solution:
Praziquantel is the medication used to treat Hymenolepis nana. This parasite is characterized by its egg shape, which consists of a thin colorless outer membrane, an inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere, and polar filaments and knobs along with yolk granules found between the two membranes. The infection is usually transient in humans and the eggs are non-bile stained and unable to survive for more than 10 days in the external environment. Treatment with praziquantel is necessary to eliminate the infection. In the given image egg shows polar filaments which differentiates it from the egg of H. diminuta.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 139.

choices.text: Routine microscopy with a negatively stained background

questions.text: A patient is suffering from Hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's urine was collected, and a sample of it was analyzed under a microscope. What approach is being utilized to make the organism visible, out of the following list?
questions.solution:
• The given image is of a Leptospira visualized using Dark Field Microscopy. 
  • Dark field microscopy is a microscopy technique that involves illuminating a specimen with oblique or off-axis light, resulting in a dark background surrounding the specimen. This technique allows for the observation of the motility of the thin, tightly-coiled, and flexible Leptospirae as they have a thin axial filament and delicate membrane which can appear only as a chain of minute cocci. It is the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize the organism when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.
  • The Leptospira infection is suggested from the hook-like appearance of the spirochetes seen in the dark field microscopy image along with the clinical history with the patient having Hepatorenal syndrome.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: Which organism is represented by the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells in the illustration below?
questions.solution:
Entero Pathogenic E. coli (EPEC) is an organism that demonstrates effacement and attachment of the intestinal cells, as seen in the image. The precise cause of diarrhea associated with EPEC is yet to be determined. These pathogens are not invasive and do not generate enterotoxins. EPEC adherence factor (EAF), a protein coded by a plasmid, has been linked to attachment in the case of infantile enteritis. The other mechanism by which EPEC attaches to the enterocyte membrane is through a chromosomally regulated locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE). This pathogenicity island, which houses a gene coding for the intimin protein, causes disruption of the intestinal brush borders and microvilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: Lymphogranuloma venereum's (LGV) incubation period is:
questions.solution:
The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LG), which is the time from when the infection is contracted until the initial symptoms appear, is typically estimated to be between 10-30 days though it can range anywhere from 3-6 weeks. This longer window of time needs to be taken into consideration when diagnosing and treating an LG infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 428.

questions.text: \(\gamma\delta\)-T cell is associated with:
questions.solution:
T cells that are mature and have a population that is small have a TCR that is of a different kind and consists of gamma and delta polypeptide chains. This gamma delta TCR is able to identify peptides, lipids and small molecules, not needing any assistance of MHC's proteins.

This type of T cell has a tendency to group together on epithelial surfaces, like skin, gastrointestinal and urinary mucosa, suggesting they serve as guard against organisms that try to enter by means of epithelial membranes. Nonetheless, the specificities of gamma delta T cells are yet to be figured out.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: A patient complained of having trouble swallowing. The diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made during a UGI endoscopy. The organism that was collected from the sample was cultivated on a specific medium, and the culture's microscope revealed the findings listed below. The phenomenon depicted below is what?
questions.solution:
After incubating colonies of Candida albicans or Candida dubliniensis in serum at 37°C for between 60 to 90 minutes, the image demonstrates the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon occurring in the form of germ tube formation. This is a rapid way of identifying C. albicans.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: Gas plasma sterilisers like STERRAD are employed in operating rooms to clean OT equipment. What one of the following is its active ingredient?
questions.solution:
• The Sterrad Sterilization System by Advanced Sterilization Products (ASP) exploits the synergism between peroxide and low-temperature gas plasma (an excited or ionized gas) to rapidly destroy microorganisms is a sterilization device that utilizes gas plasma to disinfect medical equipment in operation theaters.
  • Specifically, hydrogen peroxide is the active agent used in this device to eliminate hazardous microbes and pathogens that may be present. This technology can provide further safety and prevent any contamination while operating in the theater, enabling a safe and clean environment for all patients.
other commonly used methods of sterilisation are:-

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 35.

choices.text: Person with hepatitis B on tenofovir therapy
BK virus in patient of allograft renal transplant
CMV PCR in blood of patient of liver transplant

questions.text: Which of the following viral loads obtained using real-time PCR play no part in the course of the treatment
questions.solution:
The most precise way to identify Herpes meningitis/encephalitis is through PCR amplification of viral DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid. Yet, it does not quantify the viral load. In contrast, quantifying the viral load is a critical part of managing other three conditions, helping to anticipate the reaction to treatments.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 473.

questions.text: A six-month-old child was admitted with three days of vomiting and diarrhoea. Which enterotoxin from the list below most likely caused the condition?
questions.solution:
The protein, NSP4, by the rotavirus, is a viral enterotoxin leading to the triggering of a calcium-dependent signal transduction pathway, thus causing severe symptomatic diarrhea in infants and young children on an international scale.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 567.

questions.text: Any lipid-enveloped virus is killed by SD plasma. Which of the following infections is most likely to occur after SD plasma transfusion?
questions.solution:
During SD plasma transfusion, the risk of being infected by non-enveloped viruses such as HAV is the potential possibility, while HBV, HCV, and HIV, which are enveloped viruses, cannot be contracted through platelet transfusions.

Reference: J Thromb Thrombolysis. 2015; 39(1): 118–128. doi: 10.1007/s11239-014-1086-1PMCID: PMC7088539 PMID: 24844804

choices.text: To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
To call local social worker for help

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with a shattered forearm visits a doctor. When questioned about the wound, she explained that she had fallen and struck her hand. The doctor examines her forearm and sees burn marks from cigarettes. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. To do a complete physical examination
 
  • For any suspected case of abuse, a full and detailed history-taking and physical examination is necessary to uncover any additional injuries which could support the suspected abuse.
  • Having only a burn resembling a cigarette burn on the forearm cannot always provide a reliable diagnosis, hence a comprehensive body examination is imperative to confirm the initial suspicions of child abuse.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: What does first hand knowledge refer to:
questions.solution:
A common witness must provide first-hand knowledge in order to be acceptable in court. This means that the witness must be able to testify about facts that were seen or heard by that individual alone, rather than learned from another source. Essentially, the witness must have experienced it with their own senses, and be able to testify to that effect. For example, when testifying in a case of a traffic accident, the witness must have seen the accident happen with their own eyes.\

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 12.

questions.text: Regarding the displayed image, all of the following claims are true except one:
questions.solution:
The image shows Deadly Nightshade or Atropa Belladonna
The berries of the belladonna plant (Atropa belladonna), from which atropine is derived, are sweet, despite being highly toxic. Hence options 4 is false.

Other options 

  • Causes blindness due to mydriasis (Option 1) – True
    Atropine blocks muscarinic receptors, leading to pupil dilation (mydriasis) and cycloplegia, which can cause temporary blurred vision and photophobia. In severe poisoning, this can contribute to functional blindness.

  • Contains atropine (Option 2) – True
    Atropa belladonna is a major natural source of atropine, which inhibits muscarinic receptors, leading to effects like tachycardia, dry mouth, urinary retention, and hallucinations.

  • Physostigmine is the antidote (Option 3) – True
    Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is used to counteract the anticholinergic toxicity by increasing acetylcholine levels and reversing central and peripheral effects of atropine poisoning.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 600.

questions.text:
Match the columns given below:
A. Heroin 1. Gunchi
B. Spanish fly 2. Blister beetle
C. Abrus 3. Blue rocket
D. Aconite 4. Brown sugar
questions.solution:
A. Heroin - 4. Brown sugar
B. Spanish fly - 2. Blister beetle
C. Abrus - 1. Gunchi
D. Aconite - 3. Blue rocket

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 555.

questions.text:
Match the columns given below:
 A  
C
1. Adipocere                                          3. Mummification
 B  D
2. Liver mortis 4. Marbling
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 4. A - 4, B - 3, C - 2, D - 1
  • Adipocere: Adipocere appears chalky and greasy, and is light grey in color.
  • Postmortem Hypostasis: Postmortem hypostasis appears as a purplish-red discoloration of the skin and is usually found on the parts of the body that have come in contact with the ground.
  • Mummification: Mummification is a process of natural desiccation where the skin of the body is dried out and tightens on the body, giving it a leathery appearance.
  • Marbling of Skin After Death: Marbling of the skin after death is often caused by severe dehydration and exposure to extreme temperatures. It appears as a striking discoloration of the skin, with distinct lines and patterns that are reminiscent of marble.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: Which of these elements can poison someone and induce alkali illness and blind staggers in livestock?
questions.solution:
Selenium poisoning has long been known to cause several diseases in animals, specifically blind staggers and alkali disease in livestock. For many years, only its detrimental consequences were studied, with both acute and chronic selenium poisoning observed in the Great Plains of North America as blind staggers and alkali disease in livestock respectively.

Reference: MacFarquhar JK, Broussard DL, Melstrom P, Hutchinson R, Wolkin A, Martin C, Burk RF, Dunn JR, Green AL, Hammond R, Schaffner W, Jones TF. Acute selenium toxicity associated with a dietary supplement. Arch Intern Med. 2010 Feb 8;170(3):256-61. doi: 10.1001/archinternmed.2009.495. PMID: 20142570; PMCID: PMC3225252.

questions.text: If a person starts to serve a second employer, the new employer is responsible for his actions by?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option 2

The borrowed servant doctrine is a legal principle that holds an employer liable for the actions of an employee they temporarily borrow from another employer. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who was allegedly kidnapped insists that she is not a juvenile and left her home with the person on her own accord when questioned. Her age was determined by the court. The pelvic, wrist, and bilateral elbow X-rays are provided below. What age do you think she is, based on these?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. 21-22 years
 
  • The age in the images can be determined by the level of ossification of the elbow.
  • In the first, all the ossification centers have fused together, so this subject must be around 16 years or older.
  • In the second, the lower end of the radius and ulna have fused, meaning their age must be at least 18 years.
  • The third image has an ossification of the ischial tuberosity, indicating a subject likely between 20 and 22 years old age. Therefore, the accurate age range would be 21 to 22 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 80.

questions.text: A deceased male foetus that had been abandoned was discovered and taken by the police for an examination. The report stated that the foetus weighed 1000 gm and had the following measurements: "The head to foot length is 36 cm, eyes are open, pupillary membrane is absent, Crown Rump Length is 23 cm, testes are at the superficial inguinal ring." What is the fetus's approximate age?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. 7 months
 
  • CHL= 36 cm, Therefore by Morrison Rule, Gestational Age= CHL/5= 36/5= 7.2 or 7 months approximate 
  • At 7 months, the pupillary membranes disappear, the testes reach the level of superficial inguinal ring, and the weight is between 900-1200 gm.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: When compared to the female skull, all of the traits are present in the male skull, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Prominent frontal and parietal eminence
 
  • The determination of sex from skeletal remains plays an important role in forensic medicine.
  • Bones commonly used to distinguish between male and female include the pelvis, skull, mandible, vertebra, femur, and scapula. Features of the skull, such as frontal and parietal eminences, larger teeth, larger brain capacity, and larger sinuses, are more pronounced in male skulls.
  • Frontal and parietal eminence is prominent in females.


Fig: Male and Female Skull

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 59.

questions.text: As part of an audit, you visited a sub centre. How many newborns ought to be listed on a health worker's roster there?
questions.solution:
Subcenters are the peripheral outposts of the existing health delivery system in rural areas, with one subcenter per 5000 population in general and one for every 3000 population in hilly, tribal and backward areas.
  • Taking the birth rate of India as 20.4/1000 population and infant mortality rate as 34/1000 live births from the SRS September 2017 data, the estimated number of infants catered to by a health sub center with a population of 5000 can be calculated to be 100 (102 live births minus the 4 infant mortalities).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 555.

questions.text: In the graph below, the biggest margin of error is listed in this order:
questions.solution:
The image displays three normal distribution curves with the same mean but different standard deviations.
As the sample size decreases, the curves become flatter and the peak decreases, indicating a wider confidence interval around the mean.
The narrower the base of the curve, the lower the margin of error.
Of the three given curves,
  • Curve 1 has the lowest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, with Curve 3 having the highest margin of error.
  • In other words, the order from highest margin of error to lowest is Curve 3, Curve 2, and Curve 1.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 30.

questions.text: Which group within the National Health Mission develops plans for village health?
questions.solution:
The National Health Mission develops plans for village health through the active participation of the VHSNC.
 
  • The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee (VHSNC) is a practical means for providing communities, particularly impoverished families and children, with the opportunity to assume responsibility for their own welfare and have their voices heard.
  • This committee serves as a catalyst to support the initiating of fundamental change at a grassroots level.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 700.

choices.text: Benign or malignant, and type of surgery

questions.text: Chi-square analysis is applicable to all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is a statistical technique used to determine the relationship between two independent qualitative variables.
  • This test can be used to compare two discrete variables, such as gender or whether something occurred or not, and can tell us whether there is a connection between the variables.
