  • It can be used to compare items such as race, religion, political affiliation, and educational level.
  • However, it cannot be used for continuous variables such as heart rate/min or age. For quantitative data comparison of 2 groups Student's t test is used. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 980.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is used to assess a vaccine's heat sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Vaccine vial monitors (VMs) are used to track the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines during their transportation in the supply chain.
  • VVMs are placed on vaccine containers by manufacturers and allow users to check the colour of the indicator label to determine if the vaccine has been exposed to heat above a certain threshold and should be discarded.
  • This provides a reliable and effective way to monitor temperature to ensure sensitive vaccines remain safe.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 122.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 7.2 million units in three divided doses

questions.text: The preferred course of treatment for late cardiovascular syphilis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Benzathine penicillin 7.2 million units in three divided doses
 
  • The recommended treatment for Late Latent Syphilis or Syphilis of Unknown Duration, assuming no CSF abnormalities, is penicillin G benzathine administered in 3 divided doses with a total dosage of 7.2 million units. 2.4 million IU weekly deep IM after proper skin testing. 
  • However, if any CSF abnormalities are present, the patient should be treated for neurosyphilis.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1152.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post traumatic dystrophy with Complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient's hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This individual is likely suffering from Rheumatoid arthritis due to the presence of pain, swelling, and redness in both the knee and hand joints, as well as early morning stiffness and difficulty squatting that does not affect the DIP joints.
 
  • The presenting symptoms of RA typically result from inflammation of the joints, tendons, and bursae. Patients often complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting >1 hour that eases with physical activity.
  • The wrists and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints stand out as the most frequently involved joints
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement may occur in RA, but it is rare and usually is a manifestation of coexistent osteoarthritis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Febuxostat

Febuxostat, a nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, which is used to treat hyperuricemia and has fewer hypersensitivity reactions than allopurinol in lowering blood uric acid level in patients with hyperuricemia and gout.

Option 1, 2 and 4 Etanercept, leflunomide, and methotrexate are commonly used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male who had diarrhoea and a dairy intolerance was seen. He was later diagnosed with lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to result in lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Yoghurt contains bacteria that produce lactase therefore it can be taken by Lactose intolerance patients. 


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 153.

questions.text: A patient with known diabetes and hypertension was discovered on the side of the road in the morning, unconscious, with a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute and a bilateral plantar extensor response. What should we do as soon as possible?
questions.solution:
It is critical to check the blood glucose measurements of the patient since they are diabetic, before intervening, as a way of ruling out a hypoglycemic coma.

Clinical features of Hypoglycemia:
  • Neuroglycopenic manifestations of hypoglycemia are the direct result of central nervous system glucose deprivation.
  • These features include behavioral changes, confusion, fatigue, seizure, loss of consciousness, cardiac arrhythmias, and, if hypoglycemia is severe, death.
  • Neurogenic (or autonomic) manifestations of hypoglycemia result from the perception of physiologic changes caused by the central nervous system–mediated sympathoadrenal discharge that is triggered by hypoglycemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3129, 3130.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient who had a history of smoking enters the OPD at AIIMS with fever, tiredness, jaundice, and yellow urine and faeces. He had grown wary of smoking cigarettes over the last few days. On inspection, scleral icterus was discovered. LFT are
Total Bilirubin 18.5
Direct Bilirubin 7.5
SGOT 723
SGPT 812
What investigations will you send for ruling out acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM antiBc, Anti-HCV investigations are done to detect the presence of the hepatitis viruses that cause acute viral hepatitis.

We mainly test for Hepatitis A, B and C. Hepatitis D and E are rarely tested.
 
  • The anti-HAV antibody test is done to detect the presence of the Hepatitis A virus, which is transmitted by direct contact with infected material such as food or water that has been contaminated with the virus.
 
  • Hepatitis E is not tested routinely as majority of patients who acquire HEV infection spontaneously resolves or clears the virus. ALF is more likely in Pregnant, malnourished and patients with previous history of Liver disease.
 
  • The HBsAg test is used to detect the presence of the hepatitis B virus, which is typically spread through contact with bodily fluids of an infected person.
 
  • The IgM anti-HBC test is used to detect the presence of Hepatitis C, which is most often spread through contact with the blood of an infected person.
 
  • The Anti-HCV test is done to detect the presence of the hepatitis C virus, which is transmitted through contact with infected blood or other bodily fluids.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 74-77, 2562-2568.

questions.text: The 'a' wave in JVP means:
questions.solution:
• The 'a' wave seen in jugular venous pulse reflects right atrial contraction before the first heart sound (S1). It can be prominent in those with reduced right ventricular compliance.
  • Additionally, a cannon-type 'a' wave can occur when right atrial contraction is taking place against a closed tricuspid valve in atrioventricular (AV) dissociation. In a wide complex tachycardia, the presence of a cannon a wave can identify the rhythm as being of ventricular origin.
 
  • In atrial fibrillation, this wave is not present.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1817.

questions.text: A 60 year old man was brought to ER in unconscious state. He is a known case of COPD with fever for last 3 days. Based on the ECG provided below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of narrow QRS tachycardia, P-waves of different morphologies along with history of COPD suggests it to be Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT).
 
  • When an ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with an irregular rhythm, this suggests that the heart is beating faster than normal, with a characteristically altered electrical pattern. The presence of P waves, however, indicates that this is not atrial fibrillation, as P waves are not seen in atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Morphological variations in the P waves are highly suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) which is characterized by multiple P wave morphologies (>= 3 types) rather than one consistent morphology.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: A patient's ABG reveals pH of 7.12, HCO3 of 28, and PCO2 of 50 mm Hg. What is the patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
This statement is saying that a pH level of 7.12, which is indicative of acidosis, and a partial carbon dioxide pressure (PCO) of 50 m Hg, which is higher than the normal range from 35 to 45 m Hg, suggests that a patient is experiencing respiratory acidosis. Additionally, this statement is noting that the level of bicarbonate (HCO;) is 28 mmol/L, which is higher than the normal range from 18-24 mmol/L and implies that the kidneys are compensating for this respiratory acidosis by maintaining the level of HCO; so that the patient can maintain an appropriate pH balance. In summary, this statement is saying that the patient is experiencing respiratory acidosis with a renal compensation.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A female patient with altered sensorium was taken to the emergency room. Upon assessment, the patient's blood pressure was 88/67 mm Hg and her pulse was 60 beats per minute. 34°C was the rectal temperature. Menorrhagia, dry skin, and constipation had a history of being related. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myxedema coma is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur in patients with hypothyroidism, typically elderly people.
 
  • It is characterized by altered sensorium, hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia and other symptoms of hypothyroidism. Patent also had history of menorrhagia, drynskin, constipation.
 
  • It is usually fatal despite intensive treatment and is usually triggered by factors that affect respiration, such as certain drugs, pneumonia, heart failure and other medical problems.
 
  • Exposure to cold may also be a factor. Hypoventilation, hypoxia, hypercapnia and hypoglycemia all play major roles in the development of myxedema coma.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2934, 2937.

choices.text: A rare complication of rapid and aggressive sodium correction

questions.text: An elderly woman experienced uncontrollable vomiting for seven days, along with fluid loss in the stools, decreased food intake, and sensorium changes. She is sent to the hospital, where fluid loss is treated with quick fluids and hyponatremia is treated with electrolyte correction. The patient began to experience quadriplegia and mutism during the course of treatment. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features and the history of the patient indicate that he may be suffering from Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM), a disorder due to sudden and rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, also known as Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS).
 
  • CPM is the result of a decrease in the amount of salt in the cells surrounding the brainstem, leading to damage of the myelin sheath, which is the protective covering of the nerve cells in the brain.
 
  • Symptoms of CPM include visual disturbances, paralysis, dysphagia, and speech disturbances.
 
  • Treatment includes prompt replacement of fluids and electrolytes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: An emotionally disturbed middle-aged man in good health was having a disagreement with his brother when he suddenly felt chest pain and fainted. He was pronounced dead when he was taken to the hospital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as the apical ballooning syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a form of heart failure that is becoming more recognized around the world.
  • It is characterized by global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, and primarily affects older women following intense emotional or physical stress.
  • Symptoms may include pulmonary edema, chest pain, and hypotensive states and ECG changes that mimic an acute infarction.
  • The left ventricular impairment usually resolves within a few weeks, however it is considered to be a reversible condition.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 102, 1966.
Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1590.

questions.text: For seven days, a patient complained of having a headache and fever. When performing a lumbar puncture, it was observed that the opening CSF pressure rose when the jugular vein was compressed and returned to normal when the pressure was released. What does this mean, exactly?
questions.solution:
• Queckenstedt's test can be used to assess whether or not there is a block to the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the spinal canal.
  • During a lumbar puncture, the opening CSF pressure should be increased when the jugular veins are compressed, and normal when the pressure is relieved.
  • If the opening CSF pressure is increased on jugular vein compression and become normal on relieving the pressure on jugular vein, it suggests that there is patent subarachnoid space (no spinal block).



Reference: Pearce, J M S. “Queckenstedt's manoeuvre.” Journal of neurology, neurosurgery, and psychiatry vol. 77,6 (2006): 728. doi:10.1136/jnnp.2005.083618. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077443/

questions.text: Upon inspection, a red, painless rash was seen on the left side of the chest in a patient who had been experiencing fever for eight days and breathing difficulties for two days. Treatment entails:
questions.solution:
An eschar is black, necrotic and painless tissue, often observed on the chest and is usually linked to Rickettsial infections.
 
  • Doxycycline is usually the go-to drug for treating Rickettsial infections since the microbes lack cell wall components that makes beta-lactams and cephalosporins ineffective.
 
  • Patients are treated with oral doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 7–15 days), azithromycin (500 mg for 3 days), or chloramphenicol (500 mg four times daily for 7–15 days).
 
  • Studies have shown Doxycycline in combination with Azithromycin to be more beneficial in reduction of mortality and complications due to Scrub typhus than monotherapy with either of the two drugs.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1436, 1437.

questions.text: A RTA patient who can't speak arrives in an emergency. While being examined, the patient was wailing and unable to talk, yet he could understand what he wanted to say. Which of the marked brain regions following is relevant here?
questions.solution:
The signs of Broca's Aphasia are present in this patient, involving impaired fluency, word-finding pauses, abnormal word order and deployment of bound morphemes, telegraphic speech, reduced output and impaired naming and repetition. Area B' is associated with Broca's area, which is related to speech production difficulties. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 286

questions.text: A triad of eosinophilia, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and skin lesions are observed in:
questions.solution:
Patients with Churg-Strauss syndrome often present with similar nonspecific symptoms, a severe asthmatic attack, mononeuritis multiplex in up to 72%, allergic rhinitis and/or sinusitis in up to 61%, heart disease in 14%, and a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia in 51%.
 
  • The characteristic laboratory finding in virtually all patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is a striking eosinophilia, which reaches levels >1000 cells/μL in >80% of patients.
  • Mononeuritis multiplex is the second most common manifestation and occurs in up to 72% of patients.
  • Skin lesions occur in ~51% of patients and include purpura in addition to cutaneous and subcutaneous nodules.

Other manifestations include less common and less severe renal disease compared to granulomatosis with polyangitis and microscopic polyangitis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2810.

questions.text: After an automobile accident, a man visited the emergency room. He experienced dyspnea, chest discomfort, and anterior chest wall ecchymosis. On examination, the patient had a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute, a blood pressure reading of 80/50 millimetres of mercury, depressed breathing sounds on the left side, an elevated JVP, and a tympanic tone on percussion. The extremities and pelvis were healthy. What has been found?
questions.solution:
• The physical symptoms of dyspnea, chest pain with ecchymosis on the front of the chest wall, tachycardia (with a pulse of 120/min), hypotension (with a BP of 80/50 mmHg), diminished breath sounds, and a raised JVP and tympanic note on percussion suggests the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax.
  • Pericardial tamponade can present similarly, but there would be an absence of the tympanic note on percussion and presence of muffled heart sounds. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 374.

choices.text: Medially vas deferens, laterally gonadal vessel, inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally vas deferens, medially gonadal vessel, inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally medial umbilical ligament, medially gonadal vessel, Lateral inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally gonadal vessels and medially lateral umbilical ligament, inferiorly peritoneum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Triangle of Doom's limits is accurate?
questions.solution:
The triangle of doom is bounded on medial side by the vas deferens and on the lateral side by the vessels of the spermatic cord. The floor of the triangle is made up of the peritoneum.
The area contains the external iliac vessels, deep circumflex iliac vein, femoral nerve, and genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.


Fig: Triangle of DOOM

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1605.

choices.text: Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
Superior mesenteric artery has a normal angle between 38-65 degree in relation to duodenum
Strong's procedure is corrective surgery in which ligament of Treitz divided.
Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by an angle less than 25 degree due to loss of intervening mesenteric pad of fat

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about superior mesenteric artery syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment


Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome: It is a cause of UGI obstruction from the compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and SMA leading to duodenal obstruction. It is seen in patients with sudden weight loss like in celebrities, AIDS, metastasis. 


Fig: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1257.

questions.text: Methylene blue is injected in the peritumoral area as seen in the provided image. Which of the following procedures is being carried out?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is a surgical procedure in which a single lymph node or a small group of lymph nodes are identified and removed to determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the primary tumor to involve regional lymph nodes. 

The procedure utilizes methylene blue, which is injected near the primary tumor. The dye reaches the sentinel node (the first node in the chain that receives the lymphatic drainage from the tumor) which can then be precisely identified and removed through lymphatic mapping.

The sentinel lymph node is then examined microscopically for the presence of cancer cells; if none are found, then it is assumed that the cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes and further surgery may not be necessary.


Fig: fluorescein dye – the fluorescent sentinel lymph node is seen with blue light


Fig: blue dye (methylene blue) – blue sentinel lymph nodes and lymphatics are seen in the axilla. Sentinel lymph nodes are marked with an arrow

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is least likely to spread lymphatically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Basal cell carcinoma
 
  • Basal cell carcinoma is a distinctive locally aggressive cutaneous tumor that is associated with mutations that activate the Hedgehog signaling pathway.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a type of skin cancer that is not associated with lymphatic spread because it is a slow growing, relatively non-aggressive form of skin cancer.
  • It typically only affects the skin, staying within its layers and not spreading through the lymph nodes or elsewhere in the body. Because of this, BCC is often curable and rarely deadly.
  • The vast majority are recognized at an early stage and cured by local excision. However, a small number of tumors (<0.5%) are locally aggressive and potentially disfiguring, and on rare occasions metastasis to distant sites is seen.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1147.

questions.text: What do we mean by Class 3 hemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is ( Option 3) Blood loss between 30-40%



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 142.

questions.text:
A patient who has been intubated opens one eye to the pain with aberrant flexion. What should be the GCS score?
1. E2VTM3
2. E2VTM2
3. E2V1M3
4. E2VTM4
questions.solution:
Glasgow coma score is as follows:
 
Score Best Eye Response Best Verbal Response Best Motor Response
1 No Response No Response No Response
2 To pain Incomprehensible Sounds Extension to pain
3 To Speech/Voice Inappropriate Words Abnormal Flexion to Pain
4 Spontaneous Confused Conversation Withdrawal from pain
5 - Oriented Conversation Localizes to Pain
6 - - Follows Commands

VT is used in case a patient is intubated.

questions.text: What is the proper way to insert the following equipment in the illustration below:
questions.solution:
The position of the patient is important for safe and successful insertion of the Ryle's tube. For conscious patients, the ideal position is sitting with their neck flexed. This position allows for the stomach to empty, enables better access to the oropharynx, and optimizes visualization of the vocal cords during introduction of the tube.

For comatose patients, the ideal position is supine with the neck flexed because it provides the best access to the airway with minimal risks of aspiration of stomach contents. It also ensures a safe and secure position and clear visualization of the vocal cords.

questions.text: Where does damage control resuscitation's second stage take place?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of damage control surgery involves correction of deadly triad of trauma- hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis in the intensive care unit (ICU).
  • The concept of damage control surgery (DCS) was developed because severely traumatised patients with impaired physiology have poor outcomes after lengthy and complex surgical reconstructive procedures performed shortly after their trauma.
  • Prolonged procedures result in additional trauma and further immune and physiological derangement; the ‘triad of death’ – a cycle of acidosis, coagulopathy and hypothermia – may develop and result in multiorgan failure and death.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 351, 358.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man reports painless firm testicular swelling. AFP testing revealed a level of 3080 ng/mL. No mediastinal lymph nodes, paraaortic nodes, or iliac nodes were discovered. Small regions of necrosis and homogeneous echotexture are visible on USG. The nearby structures are normal. What should we do next?
questions.solution:
• An individual suffering from hard and painless swelling in the testicles, a raised AFP and history of testicular tumors is best treated through an initial high inguinal orchiectomy. 
  • Biopsy or orchiectomy procedures of the scrotum should not be carried out due to the associated lymph drainage which can upstage the disease. 
  • Following the radical inguinal orchiectomy, further imaging is vital.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1569.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with high blood pressure (160/100 mmHg) and a 120-beats-per-minute heart rate arrived at the emergency room. The results of a CECT are provided below. How is the condition being described being managed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Surgical repair.

The given axial CECT scan of chest shows presence of an acute aortic dissection involving ascending aorta with intimal flap separating true and false lumen. 
Debakey and Stanford classification systems are used for aortic dissection. 



As a thumb rule, Stanford type A dissections which involve ascending aorta require surgical repair whereas Stanford type B dissections which involve descending aorta can be managed conservatively by beta-blockers. 
 
  • Type A ( ascending aorta ) dissections:
    • Lead to aortic rupture into the pericardial space and hemopericardium thereby rapidly progressing to cardiac tamponade and cardiogenic shock. 
    • Critical to confirm or exclude diagnosis of type A aortic dissections as they are surgical emergencies with high mortality rate. 
  • CT angiography- Initial study of choice in hemodynamically stable patients with no e/o renal dysfunction. Shows flap separation of true and false lumen.  
  • MR angiography- More time consuming and requires administration of gadolinium contrast. Therefore, it is avoided in patients with chronic kidney disease.
  • Transesophageal (and not transthoracic echocardiography) has excellent sensitivity and specificity. It is the preferred diagnostic study in hemodynamically unstable patients. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 970, 971.
Braunwald's Heart Disease, 12th edition, Page no 827.

questions.text: Based on the results of the CT scan shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Extradural hemorrhage.

The given NCCT head shows hyperdense lentiform shaped bleed along left frontal convexity. This along with typical history of unconsciousness-brief period of alertness-again unconsciousness which is suggestive of lucid interval is diagnostic of extradural hemorrhage. 

Epidural hemorrhage:
  • Collection of blood between inner surface of the skull and outer layer of the dura
  • Associated with a history of head trauma and skull fracture. 
  • Resultant bone fragments cause laceration of middle meningeal artery. 
  • Investigation of choice is NCCT. 
  • Swirl Sign- Non-contrast appearance of acute extravasated blood into hematoma. Unclotted fresh blood is of lower attenuation that clotted blood surrounding it. 

Option B- Subdural hemorrhage is characterized by accumulation of blood between dura and arachnoid matter which appears as concavo-convex hyperdensity on NCCT scan. 
 


Option C- Hemorrhagic contusion- Intraparenchymal in location. Seen in areas of brain in close proximity to rough bony surfaces such as orbitofrontal and temporal region of brain. CT shows ill-defined hyperdensities (blood) with surrounding hypodensities (peri-bleed edema)


 
Option D- Subarachnoid haemorrhage appears as collected hyperdensity in sulcal spaces or basal cisterns, usually secondary to traumatic brain injury or rupture aneurysm. 





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 365-367.

questions.text: A Kasai portoenterostomy was performed on a toddler to treat extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Which of the following is not related to this condition in addition to the relationships shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
• Biliary atresia, a rare disease affecting newborns is characterized by inflammatory obturation of intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts. This affliction is estimated to occur in 1 in 5000 to 12,000 infants in various regions.
  • It is often associated with congenital malformations such as a double spleen and/or asplenia, absence of the inferior vena cava, and intestinal malformation.
  • In some cases, patients have additional malformations including polysplenia, preduodenal portal vein, and intrahepatic vena cava. Without treatment, progressive cirrhosis and death may occur by two years of age. 
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 383.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl who complained of persistent urine dribbling due to urinary incontinence visited the OPD. The patient is suffering from the pathology depicted in the figure below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Ectopia vesicae, also known as exstrophy bladder, is a congenital defect whereby the anterior wall of the bladder and the infra-umbilical abdominal wall are absent, leaving the posterior wall exposed.
  • Urine drips from the trigone, onto the abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other congenital anomalies.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2057, 2810, 2811.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 270, 279.

choices.text: Start next cycle of tablets from 5th day
Urgent visit to hospital and check for pregnancy

questions.text: A female is using Mala N as birth control. There was no bleeding from the withdrawal after the first strip was finished. What needs to be done?
questions.solution:
Directions to use OCPs -

a)Starting on 5th day of each menstrual cycle, 1 hormonal pill per day is taken orally for 21 days consecutively followed by 1 iron tablet per day for the next 7 days
b) Bleeding occurs when the women in on the tablets given in the last row (iron tablets)
c)Pills should be continued, irrespective of bleeding. It is very important to start the next pack on time. Risk of pregnancy increases, if the next pack is started late.

Thus in this question, after eliminating the chance of pregnancy, the next cycle of OCPs can be started.
Hence, the best option would be an urgent visit to hospital and check for pregnancy.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 575.

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.text: What should you recommend if a pregnant woman with known cardiac disease comes to you in the first trimester and has a history of warfarin embryopathy?
questions.solution:
• Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester
  • Between 6 and 12 weeks’ gestation, fetal synthesis of proteins crucial for bone and cartilage formation may be impaired by warfarin, resulting in the well-defined “warfarin embryopathy.”
  • One of the most commonly suggested regimens involves the substitution of heparin for warfarin between 6 and 12 weeks’ gestation to minimize the risk of warfarin embryopathy.
Anticoagulants in pregnancy-
  • First Trimester- LMWH
  • 2nd Trimester- 36 weeks- Warfarin
  • 36 weeks onwards- LMWH


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Asthenospermia
 
  • Asthenozoospermia (or asthenospermia) is the term used to describe reduced sperm motility.
Kartagener’s syndrome (a.k.a Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia) is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder (due to dyenin defect) comprising the triad of:
  1. Situs inversus
  2. Chronic sinusitis
  3. Bronchiectasis.
  • The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.
  • Male patients with this syndrome are almost invariably infertile because of immotile spermatozoa. The immotility is due to variety of ultrastructural defects in dynein arm of cilia and sperm tail.



Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 9th edition, Page no 683.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 205, 206.

choices.text: 5% glycine by the surgeon. The surgeon is informed by the nurse that there is a 500 cc fluid shortage during the procedure. What should be done as the following step?
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was having a myomectomy when she had a submucosal fibroid. The cavity was being irrigated with 1.5% glycine by the surgeon. The surgeon is informed by the nurse that there is a 500 cc fluid shortage during the procedure. What should be done as the following step?
questions.solution:
The difference between the amount of distention fluid introduced into the uterus and the amount that is removed via the hysteroscope, collected from the drapes, or lost in the area around the operating table is called fluid deficit.

When using hypotonic solutions such as 1.5% glycine or 3% sorbitol in healthy reproductive-aged women, a deficit of more than 1000 mL should be used as the threshold for defining fluid overload.

For isotonic solutions such as normal saline, a deficit of 2500 mL should be used as the threshold. If either of these thresholds are met, surgery should be stopped immediately. In cases of asymptomatic hypervolemia, management may involve fluid restriction or diuretics.

Patients should be monitored for signs of hyponatremia, and electrolyte levels should be monitored. If the fluid deficit in the given case is 500 mL, then surgery should continue with close monitoring of the fluid status.

choices.text: Give a generalized suture in bleeding area
Lift endopelvic fascia by putting fingers in vagina

questions.text: There was substantial bleeding and blood pooling in the Retzius area while the Burch procedure was being performed. It is impossible to identify the cause of the bleeding. What comes next in terms of medical care?
questions.solution: During Burch colposuspension (retropubic urethropexy), the fascia near the bladder neck is secured to the Cooper's ligament by an abdominally performed surgery for treating stress urinary incontinence. To stop the bleeding from the Santorini plexus in the Retzius space, the finger needs to be inserted into the vagina to lift it slightly. This technique of elevation permits fulgurating or grabbing and tying each of the specific blood vessels from the plexus of Santorini, making the process of controlling bleeders much easier.

choices.text: Give steroid cover and monitor with doppler and BPP, and plan delivery
Give steroid and take up for CS immediately
Go for normal vaginal delivery as baby is very small

questions.text: On inspection, a pregnant woman who is 28 weeks along exhibits fetal discomfort, and the results of the test (MCA Doppler scan) are listed below. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
• With this Doppler image, there is a lack of blood flow during diastole in the brain of the baby, which is indicative of fetal distress.
  • This means that an immediate delivery at 28 weeks may result in a higher risk of respiratory distress syndrome, necrotizing enterocolitis, intraventricular hemorrhage, and hyperbilirubinemia; thus, steroid coverage should be provided and the baby closely monitored until termination after dexamethasone coverage has been given.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th edition, Page no 219-222.

questions.text: Name the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the picture can be easily identified as an episiotomy scissor due to its angulated blades. 
 
  • Episiotomy scissors are specialized surgical scissors used during childbirth to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus) to enlarge the vaginal opening and facilitate delivery. These scissors typically have an angled or curved blade to make the cut easier and more controlled, minimizing trauma to surrounding tissues.
 
  • The curved design allows the healthcare provider to cut at the correct angle, usually mediolateral or midline, reducing the risk of tearing during childbirth and aiding in a cleaner, controlled incision.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 531, 620.

questions.text: Which of the following factors does the WHO consider as the most important marker of male fertility?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Spermatocyte morphology
 

Sperm morphology, which assesses the shape and structure of sperm cells, is considered a key indicator of male fertility. Abnormal morphology can impair a sperm’s ability to swim effectively and penetrate the egg, thus affecting fertilization potential. While sperm motility and count are also significant, morphology is often highlighted as a primary marker because it reflects the quality of the sperm more directly in terms of fertilization capability.

Other options:

  1. Spermatocyte count: Important but not as significant as morphology in assessing sperm quality.
  2. Spermatocyte motility: While essential, it is generally secondary to morphology in overall fertility assessments.
  3. Semen volume: This affects total sperm output but does not directly indicate sperm quality or fertility.

WHO semen analysis criteria:





Reference: Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility, 8th edition, Page no 1270.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 443.

questions.text: An expectant woman who was 32 weeks pregnant arrived with labour symptoms and little vaginal discharge; fibronectin was found in the cervicovaginal discharge upon analysis. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Preterm labour

Fetal Fibronectin:
  • A "glue like" protein produced by fetal cells at the interface between the chorion and decidua 
  • Present in vaginal secretions before 22 weeks and at end of pregnancy 
  • Generally not detectable between 22-34 weeks
  • Positive test at this time suggests risk of PTB, however false positive results are common 
  • Negative test: low likelihood of delivery within 7d


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 336-339, 793.

questions.text: When would you do transvaginal sonography in postmenopausal bleeding if the endometrial thickness is?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 4 mm

  • Many studies have validated the use of transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) as the initial screening method for endometrial cancer.

Cut off value of Endometrial thickness on TVS, for performing Endometrial biopsy in a Post-menopausal women:

  • ACOG: >=4 mm
  • FIGO: >=5 mm

Shaw's textbook also mentions the cut off to be 4mm for endometrial biopsy.

  • ln a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness and this cut-off value is 10 mm in a perimenopausal woman.
  • ln a menopausal woman with vaginal bleeding, even an endometrial thickness of less than 4 mm has the risk of cancer and the entire endometrium should be suspected to a histopathology study.

Though the answer is controversial, most appropriate answer should be chosen as 4 mm> 5 mm.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 435.

choices.text: Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman came in with a 2x3 cm labia majora ulcer that had been present for six months without healing and no palpable lymphadenopathy. Squamous cell cancer is evident after biopsy. The required treatment consists of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection
 
  • According to recent FIGO guidelines, a lesion measuring 2 cm x 3 cm with no palpable lymph nodes is classified as stage 1B vulvar cancer.
  • The recommended management for stage 1B includes a radical partial vulvectomy for the primary tumor. Although lymph nodes may appear normal upon palpation, they can still be affected, so a Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is advised.
  • If the vulvar lesion is more than 2 cm from the midline and located laterally, an ipsilateral lymph node dissection is performed. However, if the lesion is within 2 cm of the midline, a bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is recommended.
  • In this case, the optimal management approach is partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection, given the lesion's characteristics and location.

 



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 680, 682, 684.

questions.text: What is the given procedure done in the labor room?
questions.solution:
The most common procedure done in a labor room is the Non-stress Test.
 
  • A non-stress test (NST) is a fetal monitoring method used to assess the baby's well-being by measuring the fetal heart rate in response to movement. It is typically performed in the third trimester, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
 
  • A reactive result, where the heart rate increases appropriately, indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive result may require further testing. The NST is safe, non-invasive, and helps ensure the fetus is receiving adequate oxygen.
 
  • This test looks at the fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movement as a measure of fetal health.
 
  • It involves the use of Doppler to detect the fetal heart rate accelerating when the mother perceives fetal movement. 


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 123, 693, 694.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, page no 448, 450.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for Copper-T insertion:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Previous ectopic pregnancy is an absolute contraindication for insertion of IUCD. 

Absolute contraindication of Copper T insertion:
  • Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy 
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease
  • History of pelvic inflammatory disease, unless a subsequent successful intrauterine pregnancy has occurred
  • Unknown vaginal bleeding
  • Confirmed or suspicion of uterine or cervical malignancy/neoplasia 
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 572.

questions.text: Which of the following does not indicate fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
A majority of more than fifty percent of orange colored cells in the Nile blue test could indicate that the pulmonary maturity of the fetus is present, not the presence of blue cells specifically.

The Nile Blue Test is a test developed to identify fats and oils in biological samples. It is based on the principle that all fatty acid amides and esters will, when treated with alcohol and acid, give off a characteristic blue colour. This test offers a convenient way of telling apart different fats and oils without having to resort to more complicated tests such as gas chromatography and infrared spectroscopy.

The Nile Blue Test is still used today, particularly in forensic investigations, but is usually supplemented with other tests to provide additional certainty.


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 934.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 124, 125.

questions.text: A 16-year-old woman complained of primary amenorrhea when she went to the gynaecology OPD. She is 150 cm tall, with underdeveloped breasts, and the feminine phenotype. Vagina was discovered during further examination. Normal uterus was seen on ultrasound, however gonads were not seen. Investigations revealed a high FSH level and an XY karyotype. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gonadal dysgenesis

  • XY gonadal dysgenesis, also known as Swyer syndrome, is a type of hypogonadism in a person whose karyotype is 46, XY.
  • Though they typically have normal female external genitalia, the person has functionless gonads, fibrous tissue termed “streak gonads”, and if left untreated, will not experience puberty.
  • Such gonads are typically surgically removed (as they have a significant risk of developing cancer).
  • The typical medical treatment is hormone replacement therapy.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 141-143, 149.

questions.text: What is the anomaly based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy


  

Dichorionic pregnancy will have two placenta


Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) placenta


Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) placenta




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 840, 847, 848.

questions.text: A woman of 25 had artificial insemination. Ovary exhibited 8 follicles on USG. The level of serum estradiol was 808 pg/ml. What is the next step in this patient's care?
questions.solution:
Retrieve follicles should be the next best step

  • A mature follicle produces about 150-250 pg/ml of estrogen
  • Here, for 8 follicles , 808 pg/ml estrogen is not high. There is no risk of ovarian hyperstimulation.
  • Hence, we can safely go for Oocyte retrieval.
  • Giving cabergoline, cancelling cycle and not giving hcg are strategies to prevent OHSS which is not required in this case.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: You are presented with a G3P2L0 pregnant woman who is nine weeks along in her pregnancy. She had conization a year ago, but there hasn't been a recurrence according to a PAP smear. Additionally, during her past two pregnancies, at 30 and 32 weeks, she experienced preterm births. What will you do to manage this patient going forward?
questions.solution:
Next step should be USG to see cervical length
First a transvaginal sonography is done to see if the cervical length is less than 2.5 cm
 
  • Women with a history of one or more spontaneous mid-trimester losses or preterm births who are undergoing transvaginal sonographic surveillance of cervical length should be offered an ultrasound- indicated cerclage if the cervix is 25 mm or less and before 24 weeks of gestation.
  • TVS is used to determine if cerclage is needed. In those with any prior spontaneous preterm birth, the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2016) recommends transvaginal cervical length screening. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2021) also recommends this screening.
  • Surveillance extends between 16 and 24 weeks’ gestation, and examinations, are performed every 1 to 4 weeks. In those without prior preterm birth or in those with multifetal gestation, cervical length is not specifically measured. The cervix should be viewed during the sonographic anatomical anatomy examination at 18 to 22 weeks’ gestation. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 205, 206.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 160, 161.

questions.text: In an emergency, a pregnant woman is battling with a protracted labour. She is transported for a caesarean delivery. What should the nurse do to maintain the patient on the OT table in the proper position?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Supine with wedge under right hip

To prevent compression of IVC , a wedge is applied under right hip. The wedge under the right hip creates a left lateral inclination, which helps to increase venous return and avoid hypotension by making the gravid uterus shift to left side. 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 550.

questions.text: A female with a history of two second trimester abortions visits the Gyne OPD for pre-conception counselling. What will you recommend as the following investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. TVS

Second trimester abortion can occur due to structural abnormalities of the uterus. Hence , a TVS and 3D ultrasound is required to have a look at the uterine cavity.

 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 205, 206.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 161.

questions.text: An undamaged placenta is also delivered together with a healthy infant by a 22-year-old G3 P2 woman. The woman experiences acute vaginal bleeding 30 minutes after giving birth. Retained placental tissue was seen on the table by sonography. What kind of placenta is suspected?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Placenta succenturiata






Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 108, 109.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 204, 205.

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics best describes the usual amniotic fluid colour during labour?
questions.solution:
Clear colourless to pale yellow

               Colour of amniotic fluid Conditions
Colour Conditions
Green colour (meconium) • Fetal distress
• Breech presentation/ Transverse lie
• Listeria infection
Golden colour (Bilirubin) Rh Iso immunisation
Tobacco juice colour  Intrauterine death of fetus
Saffron colour, yellowish green Post term pregnancy
