Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 43.

choices.text: Wait for another 1 week and repeat TVS

questions.text: A lady presented with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. CRL was 5 mm with well formed gestational sac with calculated GA of 5.6 weeks on TVS. Next line of management:
questions.solution:
Next step is Wait for another 1 week and repeat TVS
Since the CRL is less than 7 weeks, we should wait for one more week for the cardiac activity to come.

RCOG has given definite criteria for diagnosis of missed abortion:
  • If the crown rump length (CRL) is > 7 mm and there is no embryonic cardiac activity, this is defined as a missed miscarriage.
  • If the mean gestational sac diameter (MSD) is >25 mm and there is no yolk sac or embryonic pole, this is defined as an empty sac miscarriage.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 202.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child who has ingested a button battery is immediately taken to the emergency room; an X-ray revealed that the battery was in the child's duodenum. The child is asymptomatic. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
As per the latest ESPGHAN Guidelines - if the button battery is beyond the esophagus with no magnet co-ingestion and the child is asymptomatic - the recommended management is repeat X-ray after 7 days.  Endoscopic removal is done if the battery has not been passed in 14 days or if the battery is in oesophagus/child is symtomatic. 

#controversial 
This is a highly controversial question. Answer has been confirmed with Professors at AIIMS,Delhi. Answer has been given wrong in multiple Qbanks.





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1942

questions.text: Which of the following milestones is missing in a 3-year-old child considered to have delayed development:
questions.solution:
By 18 months - 24months, a child should be capable of feeding themselves with a spoon. If a 3 year old child is having trouble doing this, it suggests that the child has not hit the required developmental milestones and should be considered having developmental delay. 

Other options
  • Option 2 - Draw square - child learns to draw a square at 4.5 years of age. Hence, not able to draw square at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 1 - Hop - Child learns to hop on 1 foot at 4 years of age. Hence, not able to hop at 3 years is not developmental delay. 
  • Option 4 - Climb downstairs alternate feet - Child learns to climb downstairs alternate feet at 4 years of age. Hence, not able to Climb with alternate feet downstairs at 3 years is not developmental delay. 










Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 44,45,50,51

questions.text: A diabetic mother delivered a baby whose blood glucose level was 60 mg/dL at birth. What other investigation does the nurse anticipate the doctor would have her conduct?
questions.solution:
Babies of diabetic mothers are more prone to metabolic irregularities than those of non-diabetic mothers, including hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.
Therefore, it is important to check for these quickly. 


Reference-:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 913, 983-985

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 78, 175

choices.text: BCG, OPV 3 doses, 3 IPV, 3 Pentavalent and 1 measles

questions.text: What vaccinations will you suggest for a 13-month-old child who is unvaccinated based on the most recent immunisation schedule?
questions.solution:
A baby that is 13 months old and unvaccinated coming to the clinic for the first time should receive
  • three doses of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV),
  • three doses of Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV),
  • three doses of Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus (DPT) vaccine, and
  • three doses of Hepatitis B (Hep-B) vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: What is the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
•  If a newborn baby is born prematurely, isn't breathing, and does not have good tone, resuscitation is necessary.
  • After the umbilical cord is cut, the initial resuscitation steps should be taken, which include providing warmth by placing the baby under a radiant warmer, positioning them with their neck slightly extended with the help of a shoulder roll, clearing their airway by suctioning their mouth and nose, ensuring they are dry, and stimulating them.
  • Mouth is suctioned before nose as chances of aspiration from mouth is more common than nose. 
     

Trick to remember- Alphabetically M is followed by N. So Mouth followed by Nose. 



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 129

questions.text: How long should a child be quarantined after being told that they have bacterial meningitis in order to stop the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Bacterial meningitis (e.g., meningococcal, Hib) is contagious and can spread via respiratory droplets. After antibiotics are started, the child is however generally no longer contagious after 24 hours. Hence, a quarantine for 24 hours after antibiotics are started is sufficient.

Other options

  • This no need to wait for cultures to become negative (option 2) or for the full antibiotic course to be completed (option 3). 
  • Quarantine for only 12 hours after admission (option 4) is too short.

Hence, isolation precautions are recommended until 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy is completed. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 161

questions.text: A four-year-old boy was diagnosed with painless genu varum. The results of a bilateral knee X-ray are displayed below. Which of the following diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Rickets.

The given radiograph of bilateral knee joint shows presence of metaphyseal widening, cupping, splaying and fraying of ends of visualized femur, tibia and fibula which is diagnostic of rickets. 
  • Rickets is a disorder of growing skeleton. 
  • Deficiency of normal mineralization seen in rickets is most evident at metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification.
  • There is an excess of non-mineralized osteoid resulting in growth plate widening and abnormal configuration of the metaphysis-
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Splaying: widening of metaphyseal ends
  • Cupping: concavity of metaphysis 
  • Findings of rickets are most prominent at the bones where growth is greatest:
  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: ulna 
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary
Other findings: 
  • Outward bowing of legs with variable deformity of the hips (both coxa vara and coxa valga seen)
  • Genu valga and vara
  • Protrusio acetabuli
  • Inward drawing of lower ribs due to inferior attachment of the diaphragm-Harrison's sulcus
  • Codfish vertebra 



Scurvy x ray findings


Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 143.

questions.text: An infant of three days old is experiencing repeated bilious vomiting. The results of an abdomen X-ray are displayed below. Which of the following will come next in the care of the patient in question?
questions.solution:
Radiographs are not always reliable in distinguishing between small and large bowel in newborns, making contrast studies, such as those with Water-soluble enemas (Gastrografin, Hypaque), beneficial for differentiating jejunoileal atresia from a meconium ileus or Hirschsprung disease, as was suggested by the X-ray that showed multiple dilated bowel loops and a history of recurrent bilious vomiting.



Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/water-soluble-contrast-challenge

questions.text: You have been contacted to declare a 12-year-old child in the PICU brain dead. All of the following indicate brain death, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Guidelines to determine brain death
 1)Clinical criteria- Complete loss of consciousness, vocalization and volitional activity.
 2)Absent brainstem reflexes- Absence of papillary responses of light, oculocephalic
  reflexes, oculovestibular response, corneal reflex, jaw reflex, facial grimacing to deep      
  pressure on supraorbital ridge or temporomandibular joint, pharyngeal gagreflex, coughing    
 in response to tracheal suctioning, sucking and rooting reflexes.
  3)Apnea- Absence of respiratory drive at paCO2 of 60 mm Hg or 20 mm Hg above 
   baseline. 
  Prerequisites:a)Clinical and/or neuro imaging evidence of acute catastrophe severe enough to explain the condition.   
   b)Core temperature more than 32°C",No drug (sedatives, narcotics) or alcohol intoxication, poisoning
   or neuromuscular blockade

    c)Normal blood pressure
     d)No confounding conditions such as severe electrolyte, acid-base, metabolic or endocrine
  disturbances
                Two evaluations, separated by a time interval of 48 hours, if <2 month  old; 24 hours, if 2-12 months old; 12 hours, if 1-18 years old; and at any  interval, if > 18 years old.
  Ancillary Test:Two tests required if <2-month-old; one test if 2-12-month-old;
 tests optional if >1 year old.
                   1)Cerebral angiography
                   2)Electroencephalography
                   3)Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
                   4)Cerebral scintigraphy

 
  • Decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not signs of brain death because they are reflexive responses that can be present in brain-injured patients who remain clinically alive.
  • Decorticate posturing is an abnormal flexed posture of the arms, hands and legs that can occur during a coma or vegetative state due to brain damage or diseases that cause a coma.
 
  • Decerebrate posturing is an abnormal posture of the arms, legs and trunk in which the arms are held outward and the legs are extended and held rigid. Both of these posturing responses occur when the neural pathways connecting the brain to the pyramidal tracts are disrupted, which can occur in the absence of death.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 580

questions.text: Unable to feel any abdominal mass, a 3-year-old boy came with umbilical cord discharge as seen in the picture. What should we do first?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is an umbilical granuloma. The next step in evaluation would be to perform an ultrasound examination to characterize the lesion, check it's vascularity and see any underlying communication with bowel.

questions.text: A 2 years old child with history of fall one year back with skull bone fracture (parietal line fracture) now presented with painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the most probable cause of the swelling?
questions.solution:
A two-year-old child who experienced a skull fracture one year ago is now presenting with a painful and expanding swelling over the parietal region. The most likely diagnosis is leptomeningeal cyst, which is also known as a "growing fracture".

This condition is common in children under four and normally involves a fracture in the temporal area that does not heal but increases in size due to herniation of arachnoid into the fracture line through a tear in the dura that was created at the time of the initial trauma.

Surgery is needed to remove the cyst and or the arachnoid tear. 


Other options
  • A growing scalp hematoma may occur after trauma, but it typically resolves within a few weeks.
  • A subdural hygroma is a collection of cerebrospinal fluid within the subdural space, which may occur after trauma or surgery, but it typically presents as a non-painful, fluctuant swelling.
  • Chronic abscess is also less likely in this case, as it typically presents with fever, localized warmth, and tenderness, which are not mentioned in the scenario


Reference-: Online resource https://www.ajnr.org/ajnr-case-collections-diagnosis/growing-skull-fracture

questions.text: Craniopagus is basically the fusion of:
questions.solution:
Craniopagus is a rare type of parasitic twinning, in which two partially formed twins remain joined at the head only. Each retain its own heart and vertebral column, but share brain tissue and its blood vessels. The degree of shared brain tissue can range from a simple association of brains, to partial brain separation with fused hemispheres, and, in some cases, almost complete brain separation. 





Other options 

Option 1 -  Fusion of the spines is called Rachipagus

Option 2 - Fusion at the thorax/head - Cephalothoracopagus

Option 4 - Fusion of thorax only  - Thoracopagus



Reference-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7342745

questions.text: What does "A" (dotted line)show in the illustration of a juvenile patient's serum immunoglobulin levels?
questions.solution:
• 'A' in the given image represents maternal and fetal IgG.
  • Maternal IgG can be transferred from mother to fetus. The fetus post-birth has maternal Immunoglobulins in circulation till 6 months of age. 
     
 

Reference:Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 180
Ananthnarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition Page no 99

questions.text: A young teenager complains that she frequently drops things out of her hands, especially in the morning and before exams. Her cousin sister has been given an epilepsy diagnosis, but there is no history of loss of consciousness. The results of the EEG examination pointed to epileptic spikes. What is the ruling?
questions.solution:
• Most likely, due to the fact that Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy tends to appear in early adolescence, with reports of a family history of epilepsy, most likely in the morning after awakening and may be caused by sleep deprivation, the diagnosis would be Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3098,3102

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse appears with acute back pain that has persisted for 10 days and urine incontinence. Fever or weight loss are not present in the past. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of a person having a history of severe backache and urinary incontinence, along with an intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse, may be suggestive of a cauda equina syndrome, which is caused by compression  after L1-L2 level when the spinal cord ends.
  • This syndrome typically presents with lower limb weakness, absent reflexes, impaired sensation and urinary retention, causing overflow urinary incontinence.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 254

questions.text: How will you manage the fracture shown below?
questions.solution:
• The given lateral knee radiograph shows displaced patellar fracture.
  • The management of displaced patellar fracture is to perform tension wire banding which will convert distraction force of quadriceps tendon into tension force and align the fracture fragments together. 
     
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman arrived with contracture in her hip flexors. What test should be performed in this situation?
questions.solution:
• Thomas' test.- During the test the hips are bent to its maximum point at the same time, removing the lumbar lordosis; the sound hip is held motionless (keeping the pelvis stable) while the other leg is lowered intimately.
  • If the knee of the affected limb cannot reach the seat it is indicative of the existence of a flexion deformity.
  • Allis Test- Used to assess for hip dislocation, developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), and leg length discrepancies.



 
  • Thomas test



    Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 349,350

questions.text: An individual who has sustained a supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex their thumb's interphalangeal joint. Which nerve is likely to be hurt?
questions.solution:
• The Anterior Interosseous Nerve branch of median nerve is the nerve most frequently injured in a supracondylar fracture.
  • This nerve supplies the flexor pollicis longus, which produces flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
 

Reference-:Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar, 5th Edition Page no 138,139

questions.text: Which of the following deformities in the image is more likely a complication of the other?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts Cubitus varus, also known as gun-stock deformity, often caused by an inadequately healed supracondylar fracture, in which the bones are no longer aligned correctly after the break.
  •    
     
     
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 102

questions.text: The symptoms of dengue virus infection in the eye consist of all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The effects of dengue virus in the eyes can show up in multiple ways, including maculopathy (damage to the macula, an area near the center of the retina that is responsible for clear central vision), vitreous hemorrhage (bleeding in the vitreous, the gel-like substance that fills the middle of the eye), and optic neuritis (inflammation of the optic nerve, which sends visual information from the eyes to the brain).
  • Blurring of vision is the most common presenting symptom followed by scotoma. Ocular findings were mostly seen in the posterior pole of the fundus, manifesting as retinal hemorrhages, macular edema, foveolitis, vasculitis, and optic neuropathy.
  • However, cataracts (cloudy areas in the lens of the eye, which can cause vision problems) have not been reported to be caused by Dengue in the medical literature.
  • Most patients with dengue-related ophthalmic complications recover spontaneously without any treatment. Patients with severe visual loss or bilateral involvement were treated with systemic steroids and occasionally immunoglobulins.
  • Prognosis of dengue-related ophthalmic complications is favorable; almost all patients had normal or showed improvement in visual acuity and complete resolution of dengue ophthalmic complications was noted in almost all cases.



Reference: Yip, Vivien Cherng-Hui et al. “Ophthalmic complications of dengue Fever: a systematic review.” Ophthalmology and therapy vol. 1,1 (2012): 2. doi:10.1007/s40123-012-0002-z

questions.text: Which of the following represents the  relay centre of an upward gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Nucleus of Cajal
 
  • The three components that make up the neural circuitry responsible for vertical gaze stabilization are the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF), the interstitial nucleus of Cajal (INC), and the posterior commissure (PC).
  • Neurons within the INC have been identified as potential players in vertical gaze retention.
  • The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) contains the premotor substrate for ipsilateral horizontal gaze.
  • The premotor substrate for vertical gaze lies primarily in the midbrain reticular formation (MRF). The rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) contains neurons for both upward and downward saccades.
  • Their axons relay to neurons in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal, which discharge in relation to vertical eye position and play a role in vertical pursuit and eye position. 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: Oculomotor nerve palsy does not cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Miosis. Complete Oculomotor Palsy leads to Mydriasis, NOT Miosis.
  • Along with the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and pupillary sphincter, the oculomotor nerve innervates four extraocular muscles: the medial, superior & inferior rectus and inferior oblique. As a result, during palsy there is total ptosis (Option 2)
  • Nerve to IO carries along with it nerve fibres supplying Sphinter pupillae via Short ciliary nerves; so there is dilated pupil when the palsy is complete (mydriasis, not the miosis). This is due to Sphincter denervation.
  • The affected eye is also turned outward (laterally), typically downward (Option 3).
  • Oculomotor nerve is the efferent nerve of pupillary/ light reflex after relay in Edinger Westphal nucleus, so its palsy leads to impaired pupillary reflex (Option 4).


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: What is the pathology depicted in the below histopathology picture of the retina?
questions.solution:
Drusen are signs of harm to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), a layer of cells that gives nourishment and protection to the retina. They appear as yellowish deposits beneath the retina and are typically considered one of the earliest stages of age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), a condition that can cause irreversible vision loss. Visual impairment can be caused by a generalized granularity and/or atrophy of the RPE, photoreceptors, and the choriocapillaris. 



Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1323.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 586, 589.

questions.text: Stenopic slit is not used for:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Corneal tattooing. Stenopaeic slit is not used for corneal tattooing.
 
  • A stenopaeic slit is an ophthalmological instrument placed in front of the eye running along the line of sight. It is used in:
  1. Fincham's test (Option 1)
  2. To find out the axis of cylinder in astigmatism for correction of glasses (Option 2)
  3. To find out the optimal site for Iridectomy (Option 3) for treatment of corneal opacities.
  • The Fincham test (performed using stenopaeic slit ) is used to differentiate between the colored halos due to Cataract and colored halos in corneal edema due to Glaucoma.
  1. Halos are broken into fractions/ scattered in: Cataract.
  2. Halos remain intact but the brightness decreases in: Glaucoma.
Image showing Stenopaeic slit:




Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 138, 139, 251.

questions.text: A patient who had cataract surgery a year prior is currently receiving medication for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient described an instantaneous, painless loss of vision. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in question has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, cataract surgery and Fluorescein angiogram of the patient shows classic “petalloid” appearance of fluorescein leakage in the late phase of the angiogram, which is indicative of cystoid macular edema (CME).

CME is a frequent complication following cataract surgery and is also known as Irvine–Gass syndrome. CME is the most common cause of vision loss after cataract surgery.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 626, 627, 630.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to treat a fungal corneal ulcer as adjuvant therapy?
questions.solution:
Atropine helps to prevent the constriction of the ciliary muscle, which can potentially lead to complications related to inflammation of the iris, such as an increased production of connective tissue in the eye, known as posterior synechiae. It is often used in the treatment of corneal ulcer as a preventive/ adjunctive measure.
  • Control of infection is attained by the use of antifungal drugs; heat is employed to prevent stasis, encourage circulation and repair, while local rest is attained by the use of cycloplegics such as atropine.
  • Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal keratitis (Option 3).
  • Pilocarpine and Lidocaine has no role in treatment (Option 2 and 4).


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 177.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man claims that nighttime driving caused his eyes to flare. His best vision correction is 6/12. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Glare at night time could be caused by posterior capsular opacification of the lens. As pupils dilate during the night, more light enters the eye, resulting in an increase in aberrations and thus creating more glare.
  • Posterior subcapsular opacities begin at the posterior polar region then spread toward the periphery. Patients have significant glare disability because of light scattering at the nodal point of the eye.

Note- Glare at night is history clincher for posterior subcapsular cataract whereas glare during day time is for ARMD. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 334.

questions.text: A 15-year-old kid complained of headache-related vision blurring. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the right eye had diplopia (seeing to the left). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The common symptom of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is blurred vision and double vision when looking towards the left with the right eye. It is often associated with a variety of brainstem conditions such as vascular, demyelinating and metastatic diseases, with the most frequent of these being multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is characterized by demyelination and is the most common cause of unilateral and bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in younger people. Therefore, the answer is demyelination.

questions.text: What is the star-marked structure and what does the angle depict?
questions.solution:
The star-marked structure is Incus and the angle is the incudostapedial joint. 

 
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 6

questions.text: Gelle's test is conducted in:
questions.solution:
Gelle's Test evaluates the effect of modified air pressure on someone's hearing when the tympanic membrane and ossicles are pressed inwards by the Siegel's speculum.

Normally, in this situation, diminished hearing occurs due to a change in intralabytintbine pressure and immobility of the basilar membrane.

Gelle's test is conducted by using a vibrating fork on the mastoid while the ear canal is being pressurized with the Siegel's speculum. The test will be positive in people with normal hearing and those with sensorineural hearing loss, however, it will be negative in cases with fixed or disconnected ossicular chains.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 25

questions.text: What is the best surgery to relieve intractable vertigo in a Meniere's disease patient?
questions.solution:
Labyrinthectomy is the most intrusive and dramatic treatment for people affected by Meniere's disease who have unremitting vertigo. It involves completely destroying the vestibular and hearing functions. To be a suitable candidate for this type of surgery, the patient must have no remaining useful hearing ability and no success with more conservative treatments, including the gentamicin injection.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 115

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a unilateral lump in the nose is also suffering from frequent spontaneous bleeding. A pink lump covered in mucosa is discovered in the nasopharynx upon inspection. Which one of the following should be avoided?
questions.solution:
CT scans are usually used to diagnose juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Biopsies are typically not recommended due to the significant risks of profuse bleeding associated with the procedure. However, if it is necessary to differentiate this tumor from other types, a biopsy can be performed while under general anesthesia with all measures taken to control bleeding and provide blood transfusions if necessary.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 280

questions.text: With cold water, a caloric test was performed on the right side. Eyes shifted to the other side. Which of the following describes how nystagmus should be interpreted correctly in this test?
questions.solution:
The caloric test is used to assess the functioning of the lateral semicircular canal, which is responsible for detecting movement of the head. As a result, this test can help identify peripheral vertigo. The nystagmus associated with this test is of the horizontal or torsional type, and will not be vertical. To conduct the caloric test, cold or hot water is instilled into the ear; the side of the nystagmus will depend on the temperature; with cold water, the nystagmus occurs on the opposite side of the ear being tested, and with hot water, it will occur on the same side (can be remembered by the mnemonic "COWS: Cold opposite, warm same").

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 45

questions.text:
A lesion measuring 2.5 to 3.5 cm on the lateral border of the tongue with induration is seen in a 55-year-old male. No concomitant lymphadenopathy exists. What is the staging as per the 8th AJCC recommendations?
1. T2N0M0
2. T3N1M0
3. T4N1M0
4. T3N2M0
questions.solution:
The staging for the given situations is T2 (tumor size greater than 2 cm up to 54 cm) N0 with no evidence of lymphadenopathy and M0 as there is no distant metastasis.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 306

questions.text: A patient came with a history of joint pain and fever for one week. For which the patient took NSAIDs following which she developed a rash and hyperpigmentation on her nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (2) Chikungunya.
  • Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish discoloration over the nose after one week of taking NSAIDs, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable.
  • This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.
  • In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (3) is incorrect)
Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010

questions.text: Which nerve biopsy helps in diagnosing neuritic leprosy?
questions.solution:
• For individuals with neuritic leprosy, it is usually the radial cutaneous nerve that is selected for biopsy as upper limb nerves are most commonly affected in this form of disease.
  • The sural nerve may also be used but radial cutaneous nerve is the preferred option.
 
  • The superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is most commonly selected for nerve biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy.
  • While any affected nerve will reveal the pathology, it is advisable to biopsy a sensory nerve branch rather than a mixed or major nerve trunk.
  • Therefore, despite the ulnar nerve being the most frequently affected peripheral nerve in neuritic leprosy, it is not the ideal choice for biopsy.

Common nerves and sites for biopsy in leprosy include:
  1. The superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist
  2. The ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border at the base of the hand
  3. The sural nerve near the ankle

Note: Nerve biopsy is the gold standard for confirming pure neuritic leprosy.



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 28.14.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1385.

questions.text: What cement component results in allergic contact dermatitis?
questions.solution: Occupational contact dermatitis is the most common and serious skin disorder seen among employees in all industries. A large amount of construction workers are afflicted by it, with cement being one of the main culprits. The most common allergen from cement is soluble hexavalent chromium.

questions.text: For laryngeal cancer, a patient is receiving a modified radical neck dissection. The surgeon elevated the internal jugular vein for ligation while dissecting the vein's tributaries. The patient's EtCO2 suddenly plummeted from 38 to 12 mm Hg, and he or she also experienced cardiac arrhythmia and hypotension. What is the most likely reason for this?
questions.solution:
• A sudden plunge in the EtCO2 reading while a patient is undergoing mechanical ventilation is an indication for an embolism of venous air, which is an extremely serious medical condition.
  • Venous air embolism occurs when air bubbles enter the bloodstream and become trapped in the venous circulation, blocking the flow of oxygen-rich blood. It is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical treatment.
  • The most common cause of venous air embolism is a displaced central line, where the central line is pulled out of the vein and air enters the bloodstream. Other causes include trauma to the chest (such as during open-heart surgery), iatrogenic trauma (where a procedure or instrumentation causes air to enter the venous system), or a forced Valsalva maneuver.
  • Diving incidents can also lead to venous air embolism, when pressure changes cause an abrupt shift in gas pressures, filling the venous circulation with nitrogen or argon.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 188.

questions.text: Doppler waveform in peripheral arterial disease in post stenotic segment is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Monophasic.
 
  • Doppler in peripheral arterial disease in post-stenotic segment shows monophasic flow with parvus et tardus waveform. 
  • It is due to reduced magnitude of blood flow through the narrowed vessel during ventricular systole.
  •  The reduced velocity of blood flow in an artery that has a severe stenosis results in a Doppler waveform that only has a single peak or phase. This is because the decreased flow velocity combined with the decrease in arterial tension due to ischemic conditions results in a type of flow that has low velocity and low resistance.





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 64.

choices.text: TCAs are better than MAO and SSRI for treatment
Variable Mood responding to positive stimulus in surroundings
Marked fatigue and heaviness in the body

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not describe atypical depression?
questions.solution:
• Patients with typical depression are usually treated with tricyclic antidepressants (such as imipramine) and electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), and they generally benefit from these treatments.
  • However, patients with atypical depression do not typically benefit from traditional treatments of depression, and they often require specific therapies such as monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), which are not typically used as a first line of treatment.
Other features of Atypical depression-
  • Increased appetite, weight and sleep.
  • Mood reactivity is present
  • Extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection
  • Leaden paralysis. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 382, 390, 572.

questions.text: A patient lives alone, is emotionally cold, shy, and prefers social isolation. They also lack delusions and hallucinations. Which personality disorder does this patient have?
questions.solution:
• Option (1) > Option (4)
  • People having Antisocial personality disorder also have impulsive, irresponsible, and often criminal behavior.
  • People with Schizoid personality disorder are loners who prefer solitary activities and rarely express strong emotions. They tend to be distant, detached, and indifferent to social relationships



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 746-750.

questions.text: Select the most common manifestation of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) in adults:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pathological doubt
 
  • The most common pattern is an obsession of contamination, followed by washing or accompanied by compulsive avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.
  • Pathological doubt is the 2nd most frequent form of obsession, commonly paired with a compulsive need to check something.
  • Such obsessions might involve feeling of potential danger, triggered by thoughts such as forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door, and often result in anxiety. Checking behaviours can result in multiple trips back to the house to double-check the stove or door.
  • Since, in this question Contamination is not given in option, so the best answer should be (1) Pathological doubt.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 422.
